This month, we’re diving into Powerful Email Marketing, because your inbox might be the most underestimated goldmine in your business. Whether you’re building community, driving sales, or nurturing long-term clients, email marketing allows you to connect on a deeper level (without having to battle the unpredictable social media algorithm).
In September, we’ll be sharing ideas, swapping tips, and uncovering what makes a newsletter not just opened but loved. From juicy subject lines to irresistible calls-to-action, get ready to rethink the power of your email list.

With Kajun Brooking
Raised on the gang infested streets of Hastings, Kajun moved to Whanganui in search of a better life. This is where he cultivates cunning comedy and hustles sticky punchlines based on life experiences. Described as slippery, quick witted and punchy, his mission is to make at least one person laugh. If he can do that, his job is done for the night and he can continue to prove to his 17 year old daughter that Dad is actually funny.

Sera Devcich
With a strong background in theatre, award winning actress Sera Devcich has turned her stage prowess to the dark art of stand up comedy. Since then she has rapidly climbed up the comedy rank, performing across the country with NZ's top comics.
Sera Devcich is a must see act.

What is Paintvine?
It’s a fun social painting class where our artists will run you through step-by-step instructions on how to create your very own masterpiece in a fun and relaxed bar setting. Perfect for dates, catching up with mates or for meeting new friends!

We provide all the materials you need (high-quality canvas, acrylic paint, brushes). All you need to bring is your creative spirit (or find some at the bottom of a glass). At the end of the night you will leave with your own painting ready to hang up on your wall.

description:
Day of the Dead - Dia de los Muertos Celebration, Day of the Dead - Dia de los Muertos Celebration
¡Celebra con nosotros el Día de los Muertos con música, baile, comida tradicional y altares conmemorativos!

About this Event

Welcome to the Day of the Dead - Dia de los Muertos Celebration at AWHI Yoga & Wellbeing! Join us for a vibrant and colorful event filled with traditional live music, storytelling, rituals for remembering the dead and delicious prehispanic Mexican cacao drink. Honour your loved ones at our ofrenda, or altar, and learn more from our faciltator, Claudio Escutia, about this rich cultural tradition.
Let's come together to celebrate life and remember those who have passed in a joyful and meaningful way. Don't miss out on this special celebration!
What to Expect:
Cleansing copal and herbal welcoming.
An opening ceremony to acknowledge the Tlalmanalli (offering and altar) with the deep sound of the conch shell in the four directions and drums sounds.
History of the day of the dead celebration.
Explanation of the altar, and the main elements for an ofrenda.
Storytelling: learn of Mexican legends like Catrinas and Xoloitzcuintle (the Mexican dog that helps the dead to find their way to Mictlan, the Aztec underword).
Remembering and sharing histories about the loved ones that passed away (optional but encouraged) 
Traditional Mexican chants for remembering the loved ones 
Atole de Chocolate, a traditional prehispanic drink - amazing in flavour, consumed cold or hot
Music to invoke emotion and imagery of contemplative natural and mystical environments
Finish with a shamanic atmosphere of relaxation and traditional chants.

description:
WINTER SERIES: Crop Swap Te Whanganui a Tara X Wellington Timebank, WINTER SERIES: Crop Swap Te Whanganui a Tara X Wellington Timebank
Crop Swap is a FREE heart-warming monthly community gathering to share what we have with each other. Think of it like a community garden potluck when each offering regardless of the amount adds up to a bounty.

Everyone is welcome - with or without something to share🌱

WHEN?
☕ Come along at 10:30am for a kōrero with our friendly community and enjoy free @Peoples coffee, usually with a scone or muffin that someone has brought along.
Swapping kicks off from 11.00am.

WHERE?
You can find us in the community room on the ground floor of block C of the Newtown Park Apartments, 320 Mansfield St, Newtown, Wellington.

IDEAS OF WHAT TO BRING
🧡Bring a friend!
🍪Maybe you like baking?
🍋 Surplus lemons?
🌱excess seedlings
📖 Have garden books or magazines to destash?
🥬Too much silver beet going crazy?
🫘Left over seeds from summer to share?
💐Got some foraged flowers?

Crop Swap is the place for you!
Note; giving isn't necessary but we do welcome koha of help / waiata / pūtea towards costs like room hire / milaka etc.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Improv On a Plate - a Comedy Show, Welcome to Improv on a Plate, the comedy tasting menu no one ordered and everyone regrets. In this unholy fusion of high-stakes improv and low-stakes judgment, three deranged guest chefs (aka format-pitchers) take the stage with one mission: serve up the most unhinged, impossible improv formats they can dream of.

Enter: Catfish Trifecta — your unsuspecting improv victims — who must swallow each cursed format whole and perform it on the spot. No script. No escape. Just raw, unfiltered chaos served à la mode.

The pitchers then get to sit back, relax, and judge the madness they’ve unleashed. It’s improv. It’s pain. It’s Improv on a Plate.

One night only. No refunds. BYO palate cleanser.
label: Arts & Theatre

*11:30-1:30* 2 hr Advanced DRUM $50
Or $80 for both

Goodbye hugs & thank yous
Tidy hall, pack drums away.

Exit hall by 1:50

~Private session time 2:30-3:30 $100ph~

$190 for all sessions, excluding the kora session.
$230 for everything Including the kora session

4:00 Sibo to airport

Info about the teacher:

Guinean percussionist Sibo Bangoura grew up in Matam – the heart of Conakry’s arts precinct – surrounded by a family of griots. His mother was a singer and his father abalafon player. Sibo absorbed the rhythm from his infancy and began to study percussion formally at the age of 12. At 14, he joined Boka Junior ensemble and then played with Ballet Matam for many years, until he moved to Australia.

Sibo currently resides in Sydney and travels to China, Japan, Singapore and Thailand to teach and perform. He plays with his brothers Mohamed and Epizo Bangoura and has a successful 8-piece band Keyim Ba

If you have ANY questions please feel free to get in touch with Bridget xo

To book your space:
Please put your NAME & which session you are doing ie: ‘OPEN DANCE’ as a reference & pay into account
Bridget Kelly ANZ 010797054191130
*PLEASE REMEMBER TO: contact me to say you have paid*

🙏🏽Thank you for supporting this event🙏🏽
Xox

description:
AI in Education: Part 1, Sovereign AI in NZ Education is a two part series that invites educators, AI developers, wh`ānau, students, and other interested people to consider how we - in Aotearoa - can design, build, and use AI tools. The goal of these sessions is to spark and support the creation of AI tools and practices that best serve the aspirations of our students and whānau, and blend well with the skills and insights of New Zealand's educators.
Part 1:
Generative AI is already in Aotearoa’s primary classrooms.  It is used by many teachers for planning and by ākonga both in and out of school.  However, policy, training, and culturally safe practice haven’t always kept pace.
In this talk, David Coblentz will provide research-based insights into:
teacher adoption patterns,
what students say they’re doing (and worrying about), and
where schools are missing guidance.
We'll also discuss what AI sovereignty could mean in education in Aotearoa New Zealand.
Then we can close with some practical steps for boards, leaders, kaiako, and whānau to support constructive and equitable AI use in Years 5–8.
*While the formal (and online) event will finish at 5pm, those attending in person are encouraged to stay on for snacks and drinks to share. Stay till 6pm or later, and get into the ideas more deeply, in a room full of good people.
David Coblentz is a Senior Statistician at NZCER. In addition to an undergraduate degree in Mathematics and Physics, David holds advanced degrees in Biostatistics (MS), History (PhD), and International Studies (MA) from the University of Washington in Seattle. Prior to coming to NZCER and transitioning into an educational research career in 2021, David worked as a biostatistician, data analytics director, and statistical consultant. David also has university teaching experience in history. His areas of interest include data analysis and data science, history education, evaluation, and AI in education.
Part 2 will follow within two weeks of David Coblentz's presentation. It will be an online event that features two or three local AI in education developers, talking about their current development projects.
We intend to record both parts and make them available via our community site - https://community.sovereignai.nz/

description:
Acting Voice - Tessa Livingston, Acting Voice - Tessa Livingston
In 2025, thanks to our generous funder Mercury, the course is FREE to Manawatu students aged 14 to 18.

The In-House Vocal Coach and Bookings Agent at BigMouth Voices, excels in Demo Reel Production, Audition Management, and provides comprehensive Accent and Voice Coaching for the agency's talents. Tessa is the newest tutor addition to 'The Voice Academy', and prior to this she has developed online courses focused on Vocal Stamina, Projection and Health. With a rich professional background spanning roles as a speech pathologist, vocal coach, voice-over artist, actress, podcaster, and content creator, Tessa brings a wealth of expertise to her multifaceted career. She is the creator of ‘The Good Talkers Podcast’, an entertaining and educational podcast dedicated to the lives of voice over artists. Her commitment to excellence underscores her reputation as a dynamic professional in the realm of voice and performance arts.

Learn how to use your voice to its full potential and spend the afternoon in the recording studio recording a piece for a show reel. Fun character voices, accents and using your voice to its fullest with confidence!

Register your interest: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdLgQss70ximb9dMOvVn4YREHt7xtZDFZ7VseEXyGt-g5Bw_g/viewform
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Advanced Flush Setting in Two Days, Advanced Flush Setting in Two Days
This workshop is ideal for advanced students who have already learned how to set cabochon stones. Over two three-hour sessions, 20 and 27 September, 10am-1pm, you will be given an understanding of the technique of setting faceted stones using a setting burr, hammers, punches and burnishing tools. This is the first step in learning to flush set facet cut stones so they sit below the surface of the metal.

Session 1 will cover the technique, demonstrations and the basics of preparing and cutting the setting. Students will be shown how to set their stones, and may begin to do this in class, but will then go on to repeat and practice the technique in their own time.
They can do this at home, or for a small extra cost, can stay on at the studio to practice setting for the afternoon.

Session 2 will pick up on the setting techniques, reminding and refining essential steps in the process. Troubleshooting can be covered in this class, as well as learning to clean up the settings. The principles of this setting technique will be covered in a few different scenarios, as some students may wish to take this skill into different styles or directions.

The option for students to have a half-day bench hire after class will also apply to this session.

What is provided: class fees cover your practice metal (copper) and stones (CZ) and detailed handouts that are useful for you to take away to refer to when practising and honing your skills.

Correctly sized drills and setting burrs will be provided in class, but students must purchase their own burrs for practice after class and any future bench hires. These are available for purchase in the studio.

What to bring: Advanced students can bring projects to set stones into, but please note the metal must be at least 2mm thick and we do not allow brass to be used as a project or practice for beginners. The metal must be copper or sterling silver.

Students should bring either a craft magnifier or magnifying lenses/glasses. If you have your own flex shaft tool you plan to use at home for drilling and setting, please also bring this along so that your tutor can advise on the best way to use it. We have two drilling machines in the studio, and these must be shared between the students, so if you have a machine, do bring it.

Practice bench hire after class $20 per person (till 4pm) must be booked in advance.

Workshop fee $195, Early bird $175 till 24 August.

description:
Fermented Quiz Night (Brewtown), Every Thursday fortnight is quiz night at one of Upper Hutt's best venues - Fermented at Brewtown!
Hosted by Sam from Gee Quiz and kicking off at 6.30pm, the quiz offers five rounds of trivia that's not too hard, not too easy, but includes content that relates to you and your crew!
So if you've got some street smarts, a good attitude, and a dash of luck, you'll be a good chance on the night. Add to the mix some bonus games, great food & drink, a stack of prizes, great banter and laughs aplenty, it's the place to be on a Thursday for a rollicking good time!
We advise booking in your team here, specifying you are coming to quiz night: https://fermented.co.nz/reservations

description:
Beginner's Knitting Class - Hataitai Community House, Beginner's Knitting Class - Hataitai Community House
Thank you for your interest in attending the 6-week Beginner's Knitting Class being run at Hataitai Community Centre.

In the workshop you will learn the basics of the craft of knitting.

Your facilitator will be Stella Peg Carruthers, a textile craft artist and eco-lifestylist who sees crafts as being a way to affect positive change in the world as a creative gesture against apathy.

Her practice is centered around sustainable materials re-use and slow creativity processes.

She is also interested in creating supportive community workshops that mirror the history of sewing in social spaces.

DATES: 27 September - 1 November 2025
TIME: Saturdays 2-4pm
PLACE: Hataitai Community House, 112 Waipapa Road, Hataitai

Basic materials will be provided including an initial pair of knitting needles and a ball of yarn to practice with. More detail about what to bring will come in an email closer to the date of the first workshop.

PLEASE NOTE: ALL ATTENDEES NEED TO REGISTER AND PAY USING THE GOOGLE FORM LINK BELOW:

Postnatal (Mums and Bubs) Yoga in Wellington, Postnatal (Mums and Bubs) Yoga in Wellington
Your first step back to movement after birth — gentle, nourishing, and designed especially for new mothers.
In this class, we focus on core and pelvic floor reconnection, body balancing, and breath — creating a safe, solid foundation before returning to any other type of exercise.
Babies are lovingly nurtured in this space while you care for yourself.

description:
Bailamos Bachata! Latin Dance Party (with free lesson), Bailamos Bachata! Latin Dance Party (with free lesson)
🔥 Please note: the event is free but it can only continue if we support the Southern Cross by buying food or drinks 🔥


🌟 Wellington’s favourite monthly Bachata Latin dance party 🌟


Join us for an awesome mix of bachata, focusing on the best sensual tracks and remixes, along with salsa and a smattering of kizomba and zouk. We welcome everyone, from the absolute beginner to the most experienced dancer. We’re all about the joy of social dancing together.

And what makes a free party with great people even better? A free beginners’ bachata lesson with some of Wellington‘s best Latin dance teachers. If you’ve never danced bachata, Latin dance or even any other dance style before then this is the perfect lesson for you. We will have you dancing like a pro in no time!

Bailamos Bachata is hosted free of charge by the Southern Cross. They love the atmosphere we bring but we also need to support them in return. We’re asking everyone attending to purchase soft drinks, food or alcohol from the bar. It’s vital we show our gratitude.

1800-1830 social
1830-1900 free lesson
1900-2100 social

Q&A
Q. What is bachata?
A. Bachata is a popular and fun Latin couples dance. It started in the Dominican Republic, then travelled to Europe and the rest of the world. It now includes a wide range of music styles and dance influences and is still changing and evolving.

Q. I haven’t danced before, is that a problem?
A. Not at all! That’s exactly what the lesson is for – everyone has to start somewhere and we’re a very welcoming crowd for beginners.

Q. Is bachata a difficult dance to learn?
A. Its origins as a party/community dance mean the basics can be learnt quite quickly, so you’ll be enjoying yourself in no time.

Q. Who are the capital bachata collective?
A. We are the combined Wellington dance schools and people teaching bachata and we really want to share this dance with everyone. We love bachata, we love our community and we want to share it with you
￼

description:
Brazilian Zouk - Introduction to Tilted turns, Brazilian Zouk - Introduction to Tilted turns
Come and join us for Improvers Zouk Block D (5 weeks).
We have some great new content for you this year and will be building on foundational movements.
The complete Improvers course consists of 6 different Blocks (A-F).
Each block focuses on a different aspect and technique of Brazilian Zouk and so they can be completed independently of each other.
Our recommendation is to complete all 6 Blocks before progressing onto the Brazilian Zouk Deep Dive classes.

In Improvers Block D you will get an Introduction to Tilted turns as well as some exercises on Floor craft and the Social Dance experience.
===Prices and payment:
- Prepaid 5 week Block cost is $90 waged or $75 for unwaged/students
- Ad hoc cost per class is $20 waged or $18 unwaged/students
Online payments can be made to Adam Polaczuk
Acct: 03-0531-0559348-25
Details: Your name and ZoukImpD
===Location:
Classes are in Studio 6, Level 5, Te Auaha, 65 Dixon Street
===Housekeeping:
- You should have completed the 4 beginner Class blocks before joining Improvers classes
- Drop in or new students, please get in contact before the start of class to let us know you are interested so we can assess your level and organise a private class if necessary to catch you up. If you just show up on the night, you are welcome to watch the class but will not be able to join in (this is to respect the learning of our regular students as the classes are progressive)

description:
Randell Cottage Annual Open Day, Tour this small colonial Cottage and marvel that it once housed a couple and their ten children. Share afternoon tea and listen to authors reading their works.
Randell Cottage is a rare example of colonial domestic architecture and is a listed historic place. It retains most of its original 19th century configuration, although modified as a comfortable home for writers from NZ and France. It is only open to the public annually as part of the Festival. The event includes a series of readings from current and past residents.
A limited programme will be offered if weather conditions are poor.

Cost: Koha
Event information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/.../randell.../
label: Community & Culture

description:
Jina (Mahsa) Amini's Third Anniversary - Movie Screening: Reading Lolita in Tehran, On 16 September 2022, Jina (Mahsa) Amini was killed in state custody after her arrest by Islamic Republic's morality police, sparking the Woman, Life, Freedom movement.
Join us for a free community screening to mark the third anniversary of Jina Amini. The Iranian Solidarity Group NZ will screen Reading Lolita in Tehran — a 2024 feature film exploring courage, literature, and resistance in Iran.
Event Details:
• Date: Saturday, 13 September 2025
• Time: Doors open 3:45 pm· Programme begins 4:00 pm· Film starts 4:30 pm (sharp).
• Venue: two/fiftyseven Community Centre
• Address: 2/57 Willis Street, Wellington (Entry via 70 Victoria Street)
• Ticket fee: Free
• Film: Reading Lolita in Tehran (feature, approx. 108 minutes)
• Light refreshments will be provided.
 Note: 
We have a one-off online streaming permission for the film. In case of any internet outage on the day, we will screen Parastoo Ahmadi’s Karvansara concert and a previously held panel discussion on "Woman, Life, Freedom: Pathways to Justice.”
label: Film & Media

description:
Breaker bay Raranga, Te Motu Kairangi, with the support of Breaker Bay Hall, warmly invites you to:
Monthly Flax Weaving Wānanga
Experience the joy of learning, sharing, and reconnecting with the art of weaving.
Whether you’re a first-time weaver or returning to refresh your skills, all are welcome. We’ll cover basic weaving techniques and tikanga (customs) and provide a supportive, creative space to connect with Māori arts and crafts alongside others.
Session Times
• Open session: 1:00pm – 5:00pm (pack down starts at 4:30pm)
What to Bring
• New weavers: 5–10 rau (blades) of harakeke, sharp scissors.
• An old towel
• Bring a bag, as you must take away leftover harakeke
• Returning weavers: 30–40 rau of harakeke and your weaving tools
• Some tools are available to borrow
• Shared kai (snacks) welcome but not required
• Bring a bag, as you must take away leftover harakeke
Koha appreciated, not required
If you would like to support the kaupapa, please email us at temotukairangi.huihui@gmail.com for koha details.
Come and enjoy weaving, learning, and connection in a beautiful, relaxed setting.
Contact
via facebook
https://www.facebook.com/TeMotuKai

Email temotukairangi.huihui@gmail.com
If you would like to koha to TMK, please email (Email temotukairangi.huihui@gmail.com) for the account details.

description:
CHEERS DAD!, Come along for an afternoon creative session of painting a piece of pottery for Dad - or with Dad, whilst sipping on your choice of brew.
This is your opportunity to get sorted for Father's Day (Father's Day NZ is Sun 7th September).
Book a ticket for yourself, your family and your dad, enjoy a creative session altogether, each turning a mug or tumbler into work of Picasso. No family dramas just a fun old time.
If Dad can't make it, make him a custom gift. Bring along your partner or your beer loving bestie!
You will be guided through the process of painting (let's get our facts straight its actually underglaze not paint!) your Mug/Tumbler. Dad will treasure his custom made piece or you could make matching family mugs!
This Pottery painting workshop is absolutely suitable for anyone...even the least creative people!
Ticket price includes:




Your own ceramic Mug/Tumbler ready for decorating


One Beverage (Beer or non alcoholic)


All the materials needed


Guidance from me to create a piece Dad will treasure forever


1 Kiln firing ~ this makes the piece strong, shiny and food and drink safe
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Chain Maille Workshop, Chain Maille Workshop
Learn the ins and outs of chain maille and create your own piece in this seven class course!

About this Event

Our medieval materials expert Achille is ready to be your chain maille master. In this seven class course you will hone in on the chain weaves that incite awe and be bestowed with the agency to create a wearable piece or majestic object of your own design. On the mysterious journey towards mastery, Achille will take you through everything from the dexterity of proper ring closing, to practicing resolve through the depths of theory and mathematics that allow you to design and execute a piece of your very own creation. This is the perfect course to begin your foray into the craft of chain maille.
This course it taught by medieval enthusiast Achille. He is a creature of curiosity and crepes, having spent the last 14 years skulking around the capital publishing “woke leftist paper” as a founder of 5ever books. He has conquered our hearts, minds, and the specialty cheese departments of the local supermarkets. Achille is a master of chain maille, now offering to teach his craft to those willing to take up the challenge.
Some materials and tools are supplied. Depending on the project you choose to create there may be extra material costs, as well as the option to purchase tools for personal use. You are welcome to bring your own bent nose pliers and wire cutters if you have them.
There are variable pricing options, unwaged/student, waged, and generous. Please choose whichever option feels right for you and your circumstances! Note that this ticket is a commitment to the entire seven week course. No chain maille experience is required, just a will to delve into the depths of metal weaves. If you're unsure about committing to this craft, perhaps keep an eye out for a one off 101 chain maille class that may come in the future.
Course Outline:Week 01 - 18th September101: Basic Skills and DiscoveryAt this class we'll explore the basics of good chain maille practice.Opening & closing rings properlyTrying out some simple structuresBegin exploring material options and how to make your own ringsHomework: keep an eye out for recycled or foraged materials that could be utilised in chain maille
Week 02 - 25th SeptemberPlay and Exploration
Gathering inspiration and looking into methods for individual projectsPlaying with recycled & foraged materialsHomework: Choose a weave from the library to try out at home or explore during the next class
Week 03 - 2nd OctoberMathematics of chain maille design, theory, and history.Math of designing chain mailleTheory & pre-planningDiscussion about ideas for individual projectsIdentify materials needed to execute individual designsHomework: Choose your individual project, identify what materials you will need, and how we will source/make them.
Week 04 - 16th OctoberBy this class you will have you project plan down. We'll be collecting/ making our materials or beginning the execution of our projects with the guidance of Achille.
Week 05 & 06 - 23rd & 30th OctoberThese classes will be open working times to make use of tools in class, ask Achille questions or help with troubleshooting, and to share our progress, challenges, and solutions with each other.
Week 07 - 6th NovemberAt this final class we will make finishing touches to our projects and celebrate our creations together! Perhaps including a catwalk of our chain maille wares, and sharing kai.
label: Classes & Workshops

Week 04 - 16th OctoberBy this class you will have you project plan down. We'll be collecting/ making our materials or beginning the execution of our projects with the guidance of Achille.
Week 05 & 06 - 23rd & 30th OctoberThese classes will be open working times to make use of tools in class, ask Achille questions or help with troubleshooting, and to share our progress, challenges, and solutions with each other.
Week 07 - 6th NovemberAt this final class we will make finishing touches to our projects and celebrate our creations together! Perhaps including a catwalk of our chain maille wares, and sharing kai.

description:
Cooking Classes, Authentic Indian cooking classes in Wellington with panaromic views over Wellington Harbour.

In each class, you will learn 4-5 recipes like: potato stuff roti, roasted eggplant curry, wholemeal, roti, naan; shahi paneer; dhal, samosa; palak paneer; gourmet chickpeas; vegetable korma; gulab jamun; kheer; mango lassi; masala chai, and many more...

The classes start at 6 pm or 10:30 am on weekends and weekdays with a 2-hour session followed by a dinner or lunch afterwards. The ingredients, copies of recipes, organic karma drink will be provided with a full course meal in a banquet setting. Custom made classes available for gluten free, dairy free and any other food intolerance and dietary requirements.The ingredients, recipes, complimentary organic karma drinks will be provided with a full course meal.

There are 2 to 8 people in each class in purpose built cooking studio. Also a private cooking classes available.

The menu for the class can be:

1) Spicy potato stuffed paratha and roti, rajasthani tomato relish, aalu matter or spicy peas- potato curry, roasted cumin yogurt raita and fresh mint- coriander chutney.

2) Shahi Paneer (cottage cheese cubes with spices and rich tomato-cashew gravy), garlic coriander naan, cumin jeera basmati rice and sweet fragrant rice pudding with cardamom. Also I will teach how to make fresh paneer.

3) Roasted eggplant curry, plain whole wheat chapatti or roti, jeera aaloo or potato curry, Tuar dahl (split yellow lentil) and Basmati rice with homemade pickle.

4) Palak paneer (creamy spinach curry with cubes of paneer), jeera rice (basmati rice with fragrant spices, panjabi chhole or spicy chickpeas curry and mango lassi. Also fresh paneer making.

5) Khadi (chickpeas fritters in yogurt and chickpeas flour soupy gravy), Aloo-Gobhi (cauliflower and potato curry),  savoury wraps with herbs and spices, fresh pickle and basmati rice.

The total cost is $130 per person, this includes ingredient cost. (As an alternative we also sell cooking class gift vouchers.The food options are unlimited and the class provides fresh and best ingredients)
Please contact for booking: indiancooking@xtra.co.nz

So just bring your taste buds! and Enjoy!!

description:
Clay Creations: Incense Holders, Clay Creations: Incense Holders
Settle in for a cosy evening of creativity, good company, and delicious food.
In this hands-on workshop, everyone will be guided step-by-step to make their own incense holder from air-dry clay — no pottery wheel or kiln needed. The design inspiration for the night will be a dreamy moon-and-stars theme, but there’s plenty of room for personal flair. Those who love to freestyle can create their own unique style, while those who prefer a little direction can simply follow along and enjoy the process.
It’s an easy-going, beginner-friendly space where conversations flow, laughter is encouraged, and there’s something grounding about feeling clay in your hands. It’s a chance to step away from the usual routine, relax into a slower pace, and take joy in making something from scratch.
After the crafting is done, the evening continues with a beautiful plant-based dinner and dessert shared together — wholesome food to round out a wholesome night. Everyone will head home with their own handmade incense holder, a full belly, and that cozy, satisfied feeling that comes from a night spent creating and connecting.

Come along and learn how to create wonderful Vietnamese dishes bursting with fresh flavours.

Depending on what's seasonally available, dishes taught may include some of the following: green papaya prawn salad (Nộm tôm đu đủ xanh), lemongrass chicken stir fry with steamed rice (Cơm Gà rang sả) , grilled pork noodle and fried rolls (bún nem thịt nướng) and beef noodle soup (Phở bò).

All ingredients provided but bring an apron, dish cloth, tea towels and containers to take food home.

Note: Our cooking courses are designed to provide a collaborative and immersive learning experience where learners often work in pairs and/or groups. Drawing For Beginners, Always wanted to know how to draw but never had the chance to learn? Join our experienced tutor and get confident with the basics of drawing.

Description A back-to-basics programme for those who always wanted to know how to draw but never had the chance to learn.
Bring along your own visual diary (A4 or larger) All other course materials will be provided.

By the end of the course, you'll be able to:

- Use tone and shading to describe form and light
- Create a final drawing of your choice

description:
Crochet for Calmness, Crochet is great for settling the mind and encouraging relaxation. Learn to do basic stitches, read patterns and complete projects in a relaxed and friendly space – left handers very welcome.

The repetitive movements of crochet help the brain make more serotonin, which can decrease tension and feelings of depression. We’ll move through all the steps from the starting slipknot to reading patterns and diagrams and making your first crochet projects.

You’ll learn to make a granny square, change colours and how to increase and decrease. You’ll also find out more about the notations and abbreviations of crochet stitches so you can make those awesome crochet projects you've been waiting to make!

By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:
- Discuss the benefits of crochet for relaxation and alleviation of mood
- Read a basic crochet pattern and recognise crochet terminology
- Choose yarns and hooks for projects
- Use a range of stitches with confidence
- Complete at least one project of your choice (granny square, keychain, garden decoration)

Suitable for all beginners, both left and right-handers and those who may have struggled to learn to crochet. Initial materials provided but bring along any yarn or crochet hooks you may have at home (don’t buy anything until you’ve discussed this with the tutor).

4 weeks, Thu 5:30-7:30pm
Wellington High School
Presented by Monique Lubberink
$129 incl. GST

description:
Fluid Art Workshop, Fluid Art Workshop
Spend an evening unwinding with paint, good food, and good company. This beginner-friendly class is designed for everyone—you don’t need to be an artist to enjoy it. All the materials will be ready for you, and you’ll get to explore blacklight-reactive and glow-in-the-dark paints, experimenting with marble and swirl effects to create something completely your own.
Since the paint takes a few days to fully dry, your artwork will stay safely with us—you’ll be able to come back on Sunday to pick it up.
It can get a bit messy, so come in clothes you don’t mind getting paint on, and tie your hair back if it’s long.
After the painting, relax over a wholesome plant-based dinner and dessert, the perfect way to finish a creative and relaxed night.
Meet your host, Alannah
Alannah has been fascinated by blacklight art since she was 15 and has been exploring different mediums to find what really stands out for 20 years. She takes inspiration from all the wonderful artists she encounters in the real world and online. She noticed that this particular type of fluid art hadn't really been done the way she does it, so she has developed her own unique style utilising blacklight reactive and glow-in-the-dark paints. Let her colour your world and explore the possibilities of fluid art together.

💛 Koha Appreciated

• Stuffed Tofu with Tomato Sauce (Đậu hũ dồn thịt sốt cà) – Soft tofu stuffed with a savoury minced pork filling, simmered in a rich and tangy tomato sauce for a comforting and flavourful dish.

• Vietnamese Fish & Dill Soup (Canh riêu cá thì là) – A light yet robust soup made with fresh fish, tomatoes, and fragrant dill, delivering a perfect balance of sweet, sour, and savoury flavours.

Join us for a fun, hands-on experience and bring home healthy, delicious Vietnamese meals! 🥢🍲✨

description:
Visit the Upper Hutt Blockhouse (8th & 9th Nov 2025), Visit the Upper Hutt Blockhouse (8th & 9th Nov 2025)
This Heritage New Zealand Pouhere Taonga property is not open to the public often, so bring the family between 11am and 1pm.

About this Event

This Heritage New Zealand Pouhere Taonga property is not open to the public often, so bring the family between 11am and 1pm!
Come visit the Upper Hutt Blockhouse between 11am-1pm as part of the Wellington Heritage Festival 2025.
"The Upper Hutt Blockhouse is one of the few remaining buildings associated with the New Zealand wars, as well as a monument to Pākehā settler anxiety, built in fear of an attack by Māori that never came. Visit today and you’ll get a sense of the defensive ‘last stand’ mindset. On both floors you’ll find a series of balistraria, tightly angled gun slots through which members of the militia would defend their posts. Keep an eye out, too, for an exposed panel where you can see the fine gravel that was packed between the exterior weatherboards and inch-thick interior boards to absorb the impact of answering gunfire. Don’t be fooled by the windows – they were added later. Originally, the loop holes you’ll spy on the walls were the only way to see out."
Inside the Blockhouse, there’s an exhibition from Whirinaki Whare Taonga, telling the early story of Upper Hutt and its Blockhouse.
We will have some knowledgeable people available to share stories, answer questions and some light refreshments. Drop in between 11-1pm and stay as long as you like!

description:
GRAND MARAMA BALL WORKSHOP, In the lead up to The Grand Kiki House of Marama Ball, join us for a night dedicated to the foundations of ballroom, commentating and Vogue Fem. This is the first time international guest Icons and Legends will host these workshops in Aotearoa, so you don’t want to miss this opportunity.
Connect, learn, and build community through a series of workshops designed to deepen your understanding of the categories, the essence, and the history that make ballroom what it is. 
Whether you're planning to walk at The Grand Kiki House of Marama Ball, support from the sidelines, or just want to better understand the culture, this workshop is your opportunity to learn directly from those who’ve helped to shape the landscape of Ballroom internationally and here within Aotearoa.

Strictly no heels.
Schedule:
Vogue Fem & Choreography by Icon Arturo Mulan (NYC Father of the International House of Miyake-Mugler) 
Get into the technique, musicality, and expression behind one of ballroom’s most celebrated styles from the one and only Icon Arturo Mulan Miyake Mugler.
Commentator Workshop by Icon Tantine Matyouz Royalty (International Godmother of the International House of Gorgeous Gucci)
Discover the art of the mic: timing, tone, and the voice that moves the room.
Essence by Legendary Overall Founding Mother Jaycee Iman (AKL, NZ / SYD, AUS)

Meet your host, Alannah
Alannah has been fascinated by blacklight art since she was 15 and has been exploring different mediums to find what really stands out for 20 years. She takes inspiration from all the wonderful artists she encounters in the real world and online. She noticed that this particular type of fluid art hadn't really been done the way she does it, so she has developed her own unique style utilising blacklight reactive and glow-in-the-dark paints. Let her colour your world and explore the possibilities of fluid art together.
................................................................................................
Booking for Thursday is recommended!
For more details and to book please go here--
https://bit.ly/eventTickets
...............................................................................................
Make Thursdays your night to connect and take a break from your week. Events range from creative workshops, wellness courses to entertaining experiences. All within a down-to-earth and welcoming space. Each event wraps up with a plant-based dinner and dessert.
...............................................................................................
Bhakti Lounge
1/175 Vivian Street
Wellington

description:
Sculpting for Tweens & Teens - Creative Arts Holiday Programme, Create your own fantastical creature from clay with experienced ceramicist, Christine Winbush. Teens will learn basic hand-building techniques to create with clay.

The pieces will be fired once, (bisqued) and can be decorated with paint at home. All creatures will be ready for pickup approximately 3 weeks later depending on drying times.

Recommended age for this workshop is tweens & teens ages 10 and above.

This workshop is part of Inverlochy Art School's September School Holiday Programme. For more teen & tween workshops including photography, jewellery making, animation and sewing head to the 'Tamariki and Teens' section of our website.
label: Family Friendly

description:
90-Day Business Plan Workshop - 24/9, Create Your 90-Day Business Plan
Are you a small business owner, unsure of where to focus your efforts, possibly feeling overwhelmed by the tasks ahead?
Introducing the 90-Day Business Planning workshop
📅 Wednesday 24/9/25 From 9:00am-1:00pm At 3/15 Daly Street, Lower Hutt
If you’ve been thinking that you need to start working ON your business
(rather than just IN the business), or maybe you are feeling unsure of
where to focus your efforts, or perhaps you are even becoming
overwhelmed by the tasks ahead - You're not alone.
Many entrepreneurs face this struggle.
This lack of direction is not only frustrating - it's a huge roadblock.
Introducing the 90-Day Business Planning Experience
In just half a day, you will be creating and walk out with a ready-to-execute 90-day plan that will give you the clarity and focus you need to move forward with confidence., and then at 30-day and 60-day online follow-up session to keep your progress
What You'll Walk Away With:
A Clear Strategy: Get into the right mindset for success as you connect your passion and goals to a focused 90-day plan that moves your business forward.
An Actionable Plan: Breakdown your big goals into clear, doable weekly steps, making it easy to stay on track and see real progress.
Inspiration & Connection: Learn, share, and grow alongside other business owners, gaining fresh insights, motivation, and a powerful networking opportunity.
Why You Need This Now:
Without a business plan, you are more likely to miss opportunities, waste time, and burn out.
Businesses with formal plans are more likely to succeed and achieve long-term growth.
The time to act is now - this session is your key to getting your business forward successfully.
Stop Going in Circles: 
Invest just half a day, where you’ll be able to create a 90-day business plan that’s ready to execute.
You'll feel empowered to move forward with purpose and clarity as you get to connect with other business owners at the same time.
label: Business & Networking

description:
Gin and Clay Emerald Green and Turquoise Blue Wall Art Workshop, A fabulous and fun workshop that combines creativity and gin tasting for a unique experience. Create one stunning large wall art piece or two smaller pieces that will be fired and glazed in either a striking emerald green or a vibrant blue around 5 weeks after the session, making it perfect for displaying in your home or as a thoughtful gift. Alongside that sip 3 delicious Gin samples from the Bond Store distillery where we will be working.

My clay classes are suitable for complete beginners or those with experience and are a wonderful way to relax, replenish and have fun. Working with clay is good for the soul! Immersing in a gentle creative activity helps to switch off a busy mind, and making tiles is fun and achievable even if this is your first time using clay.

All materials are provided so all you need to do is turn up ready to have some fun and creativity. Booking is essential so please use this ticket link: https://forms.gle/PRLZ1JH9awDYjoNk8 or email clpates@hotmail.com.

Price includes all materials, glaze, double kiln firing and a gin tasting tray with 3 gins from The Bond Store.
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Getting Started in Standup - Wellington, Have you always wanted to try stand-up comedy but don’t know how to start?
Comedian, writer, and lifelong teacher Neil Thornton (seen on TV3’s After Hours) brings you a fun low-pressure comedy workshop.
Sign up here: https://www.nzcomedyschool.com/enroll
Suggested koha: $20
Everything you need to know to get a mic in your face:
-generating ideas
-joke writing
-effective delivery
-where and how to get practice
-how to avoid many common mistakes new performers make.
Neil Thornton is an award-winning comedian with appearances on NZ TV and all over the world. In addition to his career as a stand-up comedian, comedy teacher, and writer, Neil has been teaching writing, creativity, and presentations for more than 20 years.
------
This class is also an intro to our upcoming "Complete Course" in Wellington
Wellington: August/September (w Neil Thornton)
Intro “Getting Started” Class: Tuesday 19 August 6:00-9:00pm
Class 1: Tuesday 26 August 6:00-9:00pm
Class 2: Tuesday 2 September 6:00-9:00pm
Class 3: Tuesday 8 September 6:00-9:00pm
Class 4: Tuesday 16 September 6:00-9:00pm
Graduation Show: Saturday 20 September, 8:00pm
More info: https://www.nzcomedyschool.com/
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
The Dancing & Drinking Society, The Dancing & Drinking Society (or DADS for short), is New Zealand’s premier exponent of authentic 1920s dance Jazz with Rags, Rambles, Shuffles, Drags and Blues from the juke joints, speakeasies, woolsheds and Memorial Halls of 1920s New Zealand.
With a mere 4 members, it has the impact of a full Syncopating-Orchestra, with multiple instruments being played simultaneously.
Come out for a good danceable time!
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rlWe4fbd-O4
Thursday 28th August
Doors 7pm/ Gig 7:30pm
$20
Tickets available online and on the door
https://www.undertheradar.co.nz/.../The-Dancing-And...
label: Hobbies & Interests

description:
Gorgeous Texture Earrings and Pendants Taster, A quick taster class that’s ideal as a festive outing for friends, or as a treat for you! In three short hours, learn to craft an amazing pair of textured metal earrings - from scratch!

Over this taster class, you’ll be guided through the process of heating and texturing metal, cutting and shaping with traditional jewellery tools. After completing this class, you will have one pair of beautiful earrings to wear away or gift to someone special!

You will practice on smaller texture samples to work out what texture and what metal you want to go with, and then move on to creating your earrings in warm copper, yellow brass and sterling silver - with solid sterling silver earring hooks or posts.

The earrings will be made with silver bonded onto copper, giving the bright flash of silver on one side and the dark tone of copper on the other.

Your class materials pack includes everything you need for the class to make a super cool pair of beautiful earrings. You are welcome to purchase extra materials for larger pieces at the studio.

We use quality pre-made sterling silver earring wires, or earring posts with silicone stud backs for these taster classes so that you can focus on making the main part of the earrings and know that your findings will be just perfect.

Kids aged 12 (or so) are welcome to attend the class, but an enrolled parent or caregiver must accompany anyone under the age of 16.
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Hands-on Sourdough Workshop (Neil's), Sourdough for Beginners - $120 (paid via internet banking)
Come join us for a hands-on, in-person sourdough workshop at Willow Corner Collective headquarters (aka my home)! This workshop is currently the only hands-on sourdough workshop being offered in the Nelson region - I teach and demonstrate to you and then you get to mix and practice on your own dough as we go along.
Whether you're a seasoned baker or a beginner, this event is perfect for anyone looking to master the art of making sourdough bread, learning from someone who has 10+ years of experience. Perhaps you've found all the Youtube tutorials and Instagram how-to's overwhelming and are keen to learn via an in-person class. Then this is for you! I've baked hundreds of loaves in the last year alone, sold at a market, and hosted a pop-up shop. However, my passion really lies with teaching others to bake their own sourdough in their own homes, for their own families (or small businesses - one day!).You will be taught, demonstrated to, and then you get to have a go yourself; whilst learning my tips and tricks along the way. Plus we finish by sampling some delicious, fresh artisan sourdough with some favourite toppings!
You'll go home with all you need to make a good loaf of sourdough bread:
Knowledge
Student Guide, including recipes and troubleshoot guide
Bowl, liner, bowl scraper, and razor blade... all the tools you'd need to make sourdough
Dough made in class to bake the next day at home, to wow your family/friends
Confidence to continue the process yourself
Healthy, bubbling starter to continue your journey at home
Continued support and encouragement via our own private Facebook community group, for class attendees only
Note: You will have your dough to take home after the workshop that will need shaping around 6-8pm, so please ensure that will work for you that day.Also, please double check the date when booking. If for some reason you are unable to attend on the day, due to time constraints, I am unable to refund your ticket. I am happy for you to send someone in your place, though. In extenuating circumstances I may be able to hold your ticket for a future workshop; this is decided on a case-by-case basis.
*Payment to clear in bank account two days after ticket bought, after which time your ticket will be released on to someone else. Please pay immediately upon purchasing ticket.
**All workshop info you need to know ahead of time is in the confirmation email. Please ensure you read this down to the bottom.
***I recommend you already have a pair of digital scales, and a cast iron dutch oven at home to bake your loaf with as this makes the best, artisan sourdough, with great rise. Alternatively, a large, lidded casserole dish or enamel roasting pan work also. (The lids are a necessity).
"Sarah’s sour dough class is for real life! Achieve beautiful delicious bread easily in your own kitchen. Sarah teaches you how to fit sourdough into your busy life. She clearly and passionately gives the essential information, tips and tricks to make your own loaf. I loved getting to have a go at each step in the process. I love Sarah’s catchy philosophy “The goal is good bread, not perfect bread.” This took all the pressure off, for me, and I left the class empowered with all the knowledge and skills needed to give it a go at home. I appreciated the thoughtful and well prepared resources Sarah gave us. Thank you!" - Megan
"Sourdough with Sarah was a delight! From feeling overwhelmed and giving up on the idea of ever making my own loaf of sourdough, to dancing with joy as i watch a beautiful perfect sourdough loaf get nice and golden in the homewood stove!The information was packaged in bite sizes with hands on practice in between, where we all got to experience each step of the whole process, which was cleverly condensed and prepared so that despite normally having waits in between, we were able to see it all play out in a short few hours!The process was beautifully organised with attention to detail that had us fawning, came away feeling so blessed and privileged!Sarah's glowing personality made all the information feel easy and palatable, it was so fun!Such a lovely time, great environment to learn with ease." -Melody
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Wahine In Jazz X The Listening Collective Collaborative Jam, Rooted in the values of connection, care, creativity and community, Wāhine in Jazz (AKL) and The Listening Collective (WLG) are two kaupapa-driven initiatives, aimed to uplift women and gender diversity in improvised musical spaces across Aotearoa. They invite you to join, improvise and collaborate this Wellington Jazz Festival.
The jam will weave influences from Wellington-based saxophonist, composer and educator, Dave Wilson’s model for improvisation; Finding Common Ground - fostering environments for musicians of all abilities to come together and improvise. Let this session invite you to a space where improvisation becomes a language of belonging.
Wāhine in Jazz is a Tāmaki Makaurau based organisation that advocates for and promotes the development of female and gender diverse jazz musicians in Aotearoa.
The Listening Collective is a Te-Whanganui-a-Tara based group of female and gender diverse musicians that aim to create spaces that uplift and empower individuals in the presentation of their creative work
Check out WIJ x TLC New Standards Collaboration:
https://events.humanitix.com/wahine-in-jazz-x-the-listening-collective-present-new-standards
label: Music & Concerts

description:
The Anti Social Rave Wellington: Black Out Edition| Sept 13th, After a little break, we’re back and ready to turn it up again! Join us on Saturday, September 13th (yes, it’s game day) at Nolita’s, Cuba Street for a night of high-energy beats and dark dancefloor vibes.

We’ve put together a stacked lineup featuring Dani, Not My Sister, Halinius J, and Quamay, taking you on a journey through house, techno, and closing with an epic trance finish.

Tickets: Available now on Flicket + door sales on the night
R18 event
Dress code: Your best all-black rave fit

Don’t miss the return of Wellington’s favourite Anti Social Raves.
label: Festivals

description:
How To Be A DJ - An Introduction, Always wanted to try being a DJ but not sure where to begin? Experienced and professional DJ Shan (Shannon Chng-Rawiri) will teach you all about the technical aspects, equipment and terminology, as well as the industry in general, and enable you to put together a confident short performance.

By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:

Gain an understanding of the work content and career opportunities in this industry
- Learn the difference between what a DJ is required to deliver in the following situations: Mobile, Club, Radio, Turntablist and Hobby
- Participate in various practical activities: Slip Cueing and Baby Scratch, basic beat matching and song structures

Gain a good understanding of the equipment used and terminology including:
Tables: pitch control
Mixer: crossfader, input faders, EQ, gain, cue system
Needles: back tracking
Slip Mats

Learn about Counting Bars and Matching Tempos - The difference between a Bar, Phrases and BPM - Techniques to Count, Hand position and movement etc
- Confidently present a 5 minute performance in class

The course will be held at DJ Shan’s studio at Shop 21, 71 Cuba Street, Wellington. Bring headphones, a USB with your favourite music and a laptop, if you have one. Limited to eight participants.. Bring headphones, a USB with your favourite music and a laptop, if you have one. Limited to eight participants.

Note: Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

Duration 6 weeks,
DJ Shan
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
‘Hīkoi — The Land March’ film screening, Come to the Library to watch the documentary ‘Hīkoi — The Land March’, 50 years after Dame Whina Cooper led the protest hīkoi from Northland to Wellington. The screening will be introduced by Larry Parr, Kaihautū of Te Māngai Pāho and former member of Ngā Tamatoa.

Presented by Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision in partnership with Manatū Taonga Ministry for Culture and Heritage and the National Library of New Zealand Te Puna Mātauranga o Aotearoa.

Photo ‘Participants in Māori Land March leaving Te Reo Mihi Marae, Te Hapua’, 14 September 1975, by Christian Heinegg. Ref: 35mm-87491-2 Alexander Turnbull Library.
label: Film & Media

description:
Intro To Standup Comedy, Have you always wanted to try stand-up comedy? Or do you just want to learn how to be a funnier, more confident speaker? Let's get you started in this fun, interactive one-day workshop. No experience, preparation, or talents required!

In this class you will learn to:

Develop creative practices to generate and explore comedic ideas
Craft your ideas into standup comedy jokes and routines
Maximize laughter with great delivery
Overcome your stage fright and become a more confident presenter
During class, we’ll write together, craft bits, play games, share material, and give you some fun, low-pressure practice on the mic.

By the end of the day, you’ll have heaps of your own ideas to explore further onstage, an understanding of tools used by professional comics, and the motivation and skills to brave your first or next open mic.

Note: Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Houghton Valley Community Hall Raranga, Te Motu Kairangi, with the support of Houghton Valley Community Hall, warmly invites you to:
Monthly Flax Weaving Wānanga
Experience the joy of learning, sharing, and reconnecting with the art of weaving.
Whether you’re a first-time weaver or returning to refresh your skills, all are welcome. We’ll cover basic weaving techniques and tikanga (customs) and provide a supportive, creative space to connect with Māori arts and crafts alongside others.
Session Times
• Beginners: 11:00am – 1:00pm
• Returners: 1:00pm – 4:30pm (pack down starts at 4:00pm)
What to Bring
• New weavers: 5–10 rau (blades) of harakeke, sharp scissors,
• an old towel (if you have one)
• Bring a bag, as you must take away leftover harakeke
• Returning weavers: 30–40 rau of harakeke and your weaving tools
• Some tools are available to borrow
• Shared kai (snacks) welcome but not required
• Please take any leftover harakeke home with you
Koha appreciated, not required
If you would like to support the kaupapa, please email us at temotukairangi.huihui@gmail.com for koha details.
Come and enjoy weaving, learning, and connection in a beautiful, relaxed setting.
Contact
via facebook https://www.facebook.com/TMKhuihui
Email temotukairangi.huihui@gmail.com
If you would like to koha to TMK, please email (Email temotukairangi.huihui@gmail.com) for the account details.
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Honouring Te Tiriti: Totes, What does it actually mean to honour Te Tiriti?

Join Te Waka Huia for a three-part workshop where we will unpack our nation’s constitutional founding document and explore practical ways to honour it today.

The session begins with kōrero facilitated by tauiwi (non-Māori) guides Gaayathri Nair and Krissi Smith followed by light manaaki and time to explore He Kura Toi Tangata: 50 Years of the Waitangi Tribunal, 1975–2025. After the short break, we’ll regroup for a Q&A session and finish with a tote bag-making activity led by Paekākāriki artist Selina Tuomey.

He Kura Toi Tangata exhibition ends Sunday 12 October.




About Gaayathri

Gaayathri Nair is a double diaspora person hailing from the southwest of India via Malaysia and coming to Aotearoa through economic migration in the 1980's under Rogernomics. She grew up in Tāmaki Makaurau and now lives in Te Awakairangi and works in Te Whanganui-a-Tara. She is a counsellor and facilitator, novice gardener, passionate knitter, frazzled PhD student, and shares a home with a delightfully awkward greyhound named Kevin.



About Krissi

Krissi Smith is of primarily Scottish (Clans McColl, Ross, Hogarth, Sutherland, Buchanan, Mactavish), Irish and English descent, but she grew up in Te Upoko o te Ika on Taranaki Whānui land. She currently lives in Te Ngaengae in Te Awakairangi, still on Taranaki Whānui land, and close to Waiwhetū. Krissi is a Tiriti educator, an accredited interpreter and translator, and a teacher of te reo Māori. She co-directs Kūwaha Ltd, with two of her besties: Tāwhana Chadwick and Raihānia Tipoki. She's also a māmā to one kid, one step kid, and Nanna to one moko. She has three dogs and five chickens. She loves growing kai and cooking it for people, singing karaoke, and sewing. She's a lover of learning and is getting pretty damn comfortable with not knowing the answers!



About Selina

Selina Tuomey has an Irish father and an English mother. She came to Te Whanganui-a-Tara, Aotearoa for the love of this land and a man. As a child in England, her most cherished possession was an Air New Zealand green, plastic tiki sent to her by her pen friend.

She is a mother to three sixth-generation, beautiful, young Pākehā people. Selina has a Fine Art BA Hons and is all about art and nature, acting, painting, murals, clay play and drawing. She has a love of colour, growing trees, food and going bush. Selina is a mermaid and loves people. He tangata, he tangata, he tangata.
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Intro to 2D Traditional Animation, This is a beginners course in 2D animation where you'll learn the time-honoured principles of hand-drawn animation and how to apply them to your own animation project. You may work on a project incorporating your own ideas, or if you'd rather, an assigned a project from your tutor.

Your tutor, Ross Payne, is a 30-year veteran of traditional 2D animation, and loves to share his knowledge about it for you to love it as much as he does.

In each lesson there will be examples and demonstrations of the animation principles with follow up exercises to put your new skills into practice. You'll work on your project both during class and at home, applying the animation principles to your individualised project.

You can choose to draw your animation on paper then scan/capture into your device, or choose to draw your animation digitally, directly into an animation programme. whichever you choose instructions in class will be provided to give you the skills needed for this step.

You can use any device, ipad or laptop you already own (except a mobile – it's really not big enough to do good animation on). The school does not provide any digital equipment. It's important that the app/programme is installed on the student's device before the course begins, and that they have had a play on it to get used to how it works. This is so that the student is at least a little familiar with their chosen software so that it's enough to begin learning animation techniques on day one. Additional information found at our website.

Ross will advise you on a variety of animation apps/programmes available online to use, ranging in price from free to not very much. Note - A computer mouse can be used for 2D animation, but digital pens are much easier to use. Prior to the course commencing, you'll receive details of recommended programmes to use for the course.

Suitable for a range of ages, from teens to adults.

Tuesday evenings, 14 October - 2 December, 6:30-8:30 pm

description:
Hutt Valley (Upper Hutt/Lower Hutt) Mathematics Leadership Community 2025, Are you the maths lead in your school? Do you feel equipped to lead the roll out of the new mathematics and statistics curriculum? Would you like to be part of a group of like-minded leads?
Register to join our Mathematics Leadership Community (MLC) and build your mathematics and statistics knowledge and leadership skills.
These MLC’s have been supporting mathematics leaders and teachers for over 18 years and we are excited to offer you the opportunity to be part of this network in 2025, which is shaping up to be a pivotal year in mathematics education.
Through engaging with current research and best practice, these meetings will enable leaders and teachers to:
stay up to date with changes and implement Te Mātaiaho, Mathematics and Statistics Curriculum
build capability in leading mathematics and statistics within and across their school
investigate effective pedagogy and strategies for teaching and assessing mathematics and statistics
connect and network with other leaders and teachers.

“This year the mahi we have done around the curriculum refresh has been instrumental in beginning our school’s development of our localised curriculum.”

description:

In this class you will learn to:

Develop creative practices to generate and explore comedic ideas
Craft your ideas into standup comedy jokes and routines
Maximize laughter with great delivery
Overcome your stage fright and become a more confident presenter
During class, we’ll write together, craft bits, play games, share material, and give you some fun, low-pressure practice on the mic.

By the end of the day, you’ll have heaps of your own ideas to explore further onstage, an understanding of tools used by professional comics, and the motivation and skills to brave your first or next open mic.

description:
Jewellery Making - Precious Stones in Cast Rings, Create sculptural rings studded with dazzling precious gemstones! Combine wax working and stone setting methods to produce a set of rings cast in your choice of copper, brass, bronze, white bronze and silver - beginners welcome!
All materials included in the course fee.

Description

Expanding on the Lost Wax Cast Rings class, students in this course get to add precious gemstones to their cast jewellery process!
Experiment and create sculptural cast metal rings set with beautiful stones in a variety of colours.
This beginner friendly jewellery class is also fun and engaging for returning students to diversify their skills and set stones in new ways.
Students will learn to work with a range of jeweller waxes, including hard wax, modelling wax, sheet wax, melting wax and more to create wax 'masters', setting stones in wax, as well as turning raw metal casts into shining ready-to-wear jewellery.
Students choose their favourite wax masters to be cast professionally outside of class time, transforming the designs into their choice of metals, and are returned to students to polish and finish their casts in class.

The course fee includes a range of small precious gemstones, casting 2 rings in either copper, brass, yellow bronze, white bronze, and 2 rings cast in Sterling Silver.

The bold, organic forms and textures of the lost wax processes offer a wide range of creative possibilities beyond the scope of fabrication methods alone (soldering metal sheet and wire). Setting faceted stones in wax offers a simpler and more experimental way of adding stones to jewellery compared to fabrication settings.

All materials are included in the course fee. Please bring pen and paper and your reading glasses (if you use these) and wear clothing and footwear suitable for a workshop environment.

By the end of the course, students will be able to:

Design and create unique sculptural ring designs

Carve hard jeweller’s wax ring master designs to fit a chosen finger size for casting

Sculpt soft jeweller’s wax master design to fit a chosen finger size for casting

Combine hard and soft jeweller’s wax to create unique designs ready for casting

Set faceted gemstones in wax for ‘cast-in-place’ setting methods

File, sand and polish metal casts into finished jewellery

Note: Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

Duration 6 weeks, Tue 6:00 PM – 8:30 PM
Thorn Richards

The Dancing And Drinking Society have been bringing their swing blues sounds to dance floors and craft beer bars across the capital since late 1913. When they take to the stage, guitar, horns, vocals, and kick drum blend as The Society present their favourite old rarities with exactly the sort of vigour you want for some stress relieving dance times. description:
Jewellery Making - Lost Wax Cast Rings, Evolve and advance your jewellery-making abilities with exciting lost wax methods to create rings cast in copper, brass, bronze, white bronze and silver - beginners welcome! All material costs included in course fee.

Description
In this fresh 6-week jewellery-making course, you get a hands-on opportunity to develop new techniques creating rings with a sculptural and organic flair.

The lost wax process offers a wide range of creative outcomes such as 3D forms and textures, which are not achievable with fabrication techniques.

You will design and create a pair of rings in jeweller’s wax. These wax masters will be cast professionally for you, outside class, making them in metals of your choice - copper, brass, yellow bronze or white bronze.

Later in the course you will refine your new wax shaping skills and develop a ring to be cast in sterling silver!

In the second part of the course, you will sand and refine your casts into finished jewellery.

The class offers beginners a fun introduction to jewellery making, and for those with some jewellery experience it offers a great way to advance and expand your making techniques to new levels.

All materials included in course fee. Please bring pen and paper and your reading glasses (if you use these) and wear clothing and footwear suitable for a workshop environment.

By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:

- Evolve your jewellery-making abilities with new and exciting lost wax methods
- Develop and create unique sculptural ring designs
- Carve hard jeweller’s wax ring master designs to fit a chosen finger size for casting
- Sculpt and model soft jeweller’s wax master design to fit a chosen finger size for casting
- Combine hard and soft jeweller’s wax to create unique designs ready for casting
- File, sand and polish metal casts into finished jewellery

Note: Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly.

description:
Jewellery-making in 4 weeks - Saturday Mornings, Level 2+, This class is for level 2+ and advanced students. It is not open to beginners. This more advanced class is ideal for those who are already competent at soldering simple joins, annealing, and basic tool use on their own.

Students must have completed two 4-week blocks or a 6-week block at a minimum. If you are unsure of your level because you may have done a few different shorter classes, please contact us and we can advise you.

A more advanced set of students means that your tutor can support you and the group to take on more exciting and complex challenges. They will work with the group to find appropriate projects for you and for the class as a whole. Each 4-week block may focus on a particular skill topic, rather than doing loads of different topics with each student over the block.

Level 2 students learn to solder more competently on their own using chainmaking as a way to develop their fine soldering skills. They may create a simple stone setting or ring alongside this challenge project so they have something to hone their skills that they are familiar with, as well as taking on a new skill. Their silver project could be a pendant on a handmade chain, a charm bracelet, or a more complex bezel setting.

Level 3 and above students are encouraged to work on their design skills and try new and challenging techniques. They should prepare to have one or two simple projects they can work on self-directed in class.

This class fee does NOT include materials for any student. All metals and stones, as well as quality findings and chains, are available for purchase each week in the studio. Students are encouraged to keep their silver scrap and find ways to use it thriftily in future projects.


All metals and stones as well as quality findings and chains are available for purchase each week in the studio. Students are encouraged to keep their silver scrap and find ways to use it thriftily in future projects!

description:
Kintsugi Workshop in Wellington // Hutt Art Society Inc, Kintsugi Workshop in Wellington // Hutt Art Society Inc
After several SOLD OUT workshops in Wellington here is the next one... Oct 2025

Learn the magical art of Kintsugi with Artist Ema Frost in this new Workshop. You can bring along a piece of your own pottery to restore in this beautiful style. (I'll also have a few as back up if you don't have your own piece) (All Levels)

Saturday 11th October - 10:30am - 12:20pm or 2 - 4pm


Ema has been teaching Kintsugi for 5+ years and regularly travels to Japan to study and learn new techniques. Ema's illustrations and ceramic works sit in many of our countries best galleries, and whose products and merchandise sell in the most stylish design stores and gallery shops. Her style is enchanting - quirky, feminine and colourful, and clearly influenced by her travels throughout the world, usually off the beaten track.

Have you ever wanted to try Kintsugi.... It's an ancient Japanese art form where you fix broken pottery with gold - making its imperfections its beauty. - A truly wonderful philosophy to live by. Nothing is ever really broken but new life and meaning is brought back making your piece a work of art and truly something special. You can also apply this technique on various materials like glass, wood, greenstone and shells.

Kintsugi
It's called kintsugi (金継ぎ), or kintsukuroi (金繕い), literally golden (“kin”) and repair (“tsugi”). This traditional Japanese art uses a precious metal – liquid gold, liquid silver or lacquer dusted with powdered gold – to bring together the pieces of a broken pottery item and at the same time enhance the breaks.

You will take away your wonderful finished work, plus your new skills which will enable you to further your own Kintsugi in your own time.

What you will take away:
A finished artwork piece
A understanding of Kintsugi
Knowledge and History of this beautiful art form.

description:
Knitting for Beginners, Always wanted to learn how to knit but never been sure where to begin? Join craft tutor Stella Carruthers as she teaches the basic principles of knitting in this fun, informative and supportive class. Come along and learn the essential building blocks of knitting, using only knitting needles, yarn and your hands!
Come and reap the benefits of a mindful and meditative craft-form. Meet other people interested in making things with their hands, chat over crafting and find out what the craft craze is all about.

Join crafter Stella as she shares her ten years plus knitting experience in this beginner’s knitting class that supports each student as an individual learner.

Master basic knitting techniques, learn how to cast stitches on and off the needles, explore the knit and purl stitches and practice how to hold the needles in a way that is comfortable for you - then learn how to knit in the English style.

Knitting needles and yarn are included in the course fee, but you're welcome to bring along your own 4-ply yarn if you wish.

By the end of the course you will have created two squares of knitting, one in basic garter stitch and the other utilising both knit and purl stitches to create the knitted fabric called stocking stitch.

Your 4-week block will give you time to learn the basics and then create one or more leadlight projects.

This class is ideal for creating sun-catchers or small decorative projects for beginners, or working on slightly more complex pieces for those with some experience.

Beginners will start by planning their design, then learning to cut the glass, and prepare it before foiling and soldering each piece, creating a simple elegant clear glass starter project.

Beautiful coloured glass, copper foil and leadlight solder are then available to purchase as required for your other projects.

This is a warm and friendly class with excellent support and learning for complete beginners and more advanced students. All tools are supplied, though you are welcome to bring your own tools and glass if you have them.

description:
Georgina Beyer – Diamonds are Forever, Georgina Beyer – Diamonds are Forever
STARTS: 1pm, SUNDAY 5 OCT

In 2004, Georgina Beyer, the first openly transgender Member of Parliament in the world, famously confronted members of Destiny Church during the Enough Is Enough rally on the grounds of Parliament.

Never a bystander, Georgina faced down the bigots, telling them straight, “Your hatred is totally intolerable!” This was just one of many significant moments that shaped the life of the extraordinary Georgina Beyer.

Born in Wellington, Georgina went on to have an unprecedented local, national and international impact through her commitment to equality and her desire to give everyone the opportunity to reach their full potential in society.

Join us for this special 90-minute walking tour as we pay tribute to the late Georgina (1957–2023) by visiting locations around central Wellington that shaped her journey. Along the way, we’ll honour some of her heroes and listen to first-hand archival audio clips that showcase her humour and resilience.

Georgina’s story is defiantly optimistic – confronting hardship and using her lived experience to change the world for the better.

Time/Date: 1pm, Sunday 5 October 2025

Starts: meet outside St Peters Church, 211 Willis Street

Ends: Vivian Street

Duration: 90 minutes

Cost / Bookings: the tour is free but you do need to register here: https://walktoursnz.wordpress.com/book/

Accessibility information: the tour is on flat public footpaths. Tours are limited to approximately 20 walkers.

Image courtesy of the amazing Kym Strathdee

Whether you’re building your own career or building the teams of tomorrow, this is a conversation you won’t want to miss.

Everyone racing (including passengers) must wear a compliant helmet, long sleeves, long pants, and enclosed shoes.

If you’re new to drag racing, check out our Getting Started guide on the website – it has all the details you’ll need to know before race day.

Hot Rod & Classic Car Display:
Preferential parking is available for hot rods and classics – roll up and be part of the show in the pits and display area.

Make this Father’s Day one to remember – whether you’re on the start line, riding shotgun, or watching from the stands, Dads Drags is the place to be this Fathers Day!

description:
Life Drawing - Beginners, Life drawing is a basic staple for all artists. This course will assist you in developing the necessary skills required to render the human form in a 2D manner.

Description
This course will help artists and designers at all levels to develop their life-drawing skills. Starting with an exploration of structure, form, shape and proportion, we will progress through foreshortening while creating illusions of depth and atmosphere using light sourcing. You will also learn to draw using a range of media.

Please bring an A2 sketch pad, 2B and 4B pencils and an eraser. Cost of model included in course fee.

By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:

- Draw the human form
- Comprehend structure and shape
- Demonstrate fundamental drawing skills
- Be familiar with proportion
- Use drawing media to create tonal range

Note: Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly.
