description:
Snacks Amore, When the host brings you bread, instead of a red flag...Snacks Amore!
Amuse Snack Bar invites food lovers to ditch the dating apps for one delicious night of light-hearted speed dating and snack-based bonding at their Euro-inspired aperitivo haven. Whether you are after a snack (human) or a snack (sustenance), you're guaranteed to leave with a full heart and a satisfied appetite.
Each attendee will enjoy 12 mini dates and 6 courses of Italian-inspired snacklets – cacio e pepe, agrodolce, pasta alla norma, porchetta, and zabaione, all served in perfect bite-sized form. A glass of Lambrusco kicks off the evening, with a cheeky mini tiramisu maritozzo to take home. Throughout the event, wines curated by the charming Richard Klein of Artigiano Imports will be on offer, alongside Amuse’s house spritz, Negroni, and Parrotdog Lager.
The atmosphere is relaxed and welcoming – more aperitivo hour than high-pressure matchmaking. The Amuse team, also musicians, will guide the evening with playful icebreakers, musical moments, and a light-touch structure that makes meeting new people easy and enjoyable.
Two themed evenings allow guests to choose their best fit:

Evening 1: General Assembly
Grouped on the night by chosen generation:
• 5:30pm – Millennials (28–45)
• 7:30pm – Gen X (40–60)

Evening 2: Rainbow Night
Grouped by dating preference.
• 6:30pm – she for her upstairs, he for him downstairs.

The event warmly welcomes all gender identities and sexual orientations. Attendees will be asked to indicate who they’re interested in dating at checkout, but gender identity remains private unless individuals wish to share it. Symbols and nametags on the night will help create a fun and inclusive vibe. Amuse Snack Bar is proud to be an LGBTQIA+ friendly space.
label: Food & Drink

description:
Mischief Night Murder Mystery Feast with Chef Max Gordy, 30 October, 🎃 Step inside, if you dare... on the eve of Halloween. It's a Mischief Night* full of tricks and frights!
👻 A chilling murder mystery unfolds over a hauntingly good three-course Halloween dinner by Chef Max Gordy.
Gather your cleverest friends... who will crack the case first: the detectives or the villains?
Expect twists, laughter, and a touch of fright, with spot prizes through the night — plus a reward for the best-dressed.
🍽️ Award-winning chef Max Gordy (Graze Wine Bar) will conjure up a frightfully delicious Halloween-themed feast.
🥂 Your ticket includes one complimentary alcoholic beverage (with more available to purchase on the night).
TICKET TYPES
Round up your squad of six to solve the mystery and devour a fiendishly good feast for $666.
Have a frightening four-some? Book a table for $444.
Spooky single seats available for $111... we will seat you at a mystery table for some mischief!
VENUE
60 Dixon Street is up a flight of steep steps – with only one way in.
FUNDRAISING
Every ticket sold helps Kaibosh ensure that no good food is left to die.  
By joining us for this night of spooky fun, you’ll be directly helping us rescue quality surplus kai and get it to those who need it most.
*What is Mischief Night? In parts of Pennsylvania and New Jersey in the eastern USA, 30 October is called “Mischief Night.” The tradition refers to the eve of Halloween in which children and teenagers celebrate the holiday one night early with pranks, tricks and more. While in New England, some call it Cabbage Night...
Join us to experience Chef Max Gordy's culinary take on Mischief Night in Pōneke!
label: Food & Drink

description:
Shady Nasty, Debut Aotearoa Shows, Following the release of their debut album TREK and a string of sold-out shows across Sydney (Eora), Brisbane (Meanjin), and Melbourne (Naarm), Sydney post-punk trio Shady Nasty announce their debut tour in Aotearoa/New Zealand this September.

A world bound by modding cars, immigrant heritage and digital obsessions, Kevin Stathis, Haydn Green and Luca Watson, together play a left-field breed of punk that recalibrates their formal training to its most uncustomary extremes.

Wherever they play and no matter the room size, devout adherents clammer to propel a heaving mosh. Experience TREK live as Shady Nasty debut the record with an all-new live show, with special guests to be announced.
label: Music & Concerts

description:
Ignite Alumni Pub Quiz, Are you a past consultant with Ignite? Do you want to reconnect with other consultants, test your general knowledge, and be in with a chance to win some cool prizes? Then you are invited to our very first IGNITE ALUMNI EVENT - Pub Quiz Style!
Ignite Consultants Wellington is hosting a Pub Quiz for all consultants past and present. This is your opportunity to catch up with other consultants outside of your projects, meet new people, and show off your quiz skills. Your time as a consultant might have come to an end but you are always part of the Ignite whānau as our Alumni!
The quiz will be held at the Cavern Club on the 7th of October, 2025 kicking off at 7pm. You are welcome to make your own teams, or you can choose to be allocated a team. We will do our best to put you with consultants from the same project as much as possible. If you're a Dunedin alum we would love to have you there as well! Teams are 4-6 people.
Tickets for this event ARE LIMITED- so get in quick! A $5 registration fee will go towards the running of the event and supporting Ignite.
We would really love to see you there our amazing Alumni!

description:
Rathkeale Christmas Fete 2025, Welcome to the Rathkeale Christmas Fête 2025! Walk through the gates of Rathkeale College on 1st November and be welcomed by a diverse range of colourful stalls, the aroma of freshy cooked food and plenty of festive inspiration.

Now in its 22nd year, the Christmas Fête has become a must-do event on the Wairarapa spring calendar. Stallholders travel from around the North Island to sell their wares and offer Christmas shoppers loads of inspiration. From festive decorations, clothing, arts and crafts, to flowers, toys and plants – there is something for everyone.

Gourmet food is always a highlight at the Fête - think freshly made gourmet burgers, lamb & mint sausages, wraps, curry, salads, and the ever-popular berries & ice-cream - there is always a huge variety of flavours to tempt the taste buds. Devonshire Teas and home baking served in the Rathkeale Homestead rose garden is a time-honoured tradition while refreshing cold drinks can be sipped on as visitors listen to live music performed by students at various times throughout the day. The popular Christmas cake stall features again this year - but visitors are encouraged to get in early as the cakes often sell out by midday.

The beauty of this Fête is that it’s a day out for the whole family. In addition to the 120 plus stalls, there is plenty to entertain the children including facepainting and magic shows throughout the day.

Visitors can also explore the beautiful, expansive grounds of Rathkeale College including the school gardens designed by Alfred Buxton, the Greek Amphitheatre and the 3km eco-trail which weaves through large stands of native trees, including ancient kahikatea.

Eftpos is available, but we strongly recommend that visitors bring cash.

Koha/gold coin entry.
Rathkeale College is a five-minute drive north of Masterton in the Wairarapa.
label: Festivals

description:
Meet the Characters from Kiwi's Big Hararei show at Zealandia!, These school holidays, Zealandia Te Māra a Tāne will become the playground of a host of incredible critters from Circa Theatre's current children's show Kiwi's Big Hararei!
Brought to you by award-winning company, Horse With No Name, this free "Meet the Characters" event features an amazing array of manu, including kiwi, tūī, kārearea, and tītīpounamu.
The cast of Kiwi's Big Hararei will wow tamariki with a sneak peek of their show, featuring original waiata by Aotearoa singer-songwriter, Benny Tipene. They will also kōrero about the unique adaptations of these manu and how we can all be kaitiaki of them.
Bring your tamariki along to engage with these colourful creatures, with stunning costume design by GRIDLEY by Victoria. Musical performance, native biodiversity, and interactive theatre combine on the Heritage Lawn for an afternoon of spring fun in the sun! The team of talented children’s entertainers from Horse With No Name is so excited to share a snippet of their show Kiwi's Big Hararei with you.
Kiwi's Big Hararei will be playing at Circa Theatre over the school holidays until 4 October: https://www.circa.co.nz/package/kiwis-big-hararei/
General Admission fees to the sanctuary apply, free entry for members. Should the weather turn, this event will be held the foyer of the Visitor Centre on the ground floor. Overflow carparking is available at Birdwood Street during the busy school holiday period.
label: Family Friendly

description:
Rongotai Labour Film Evening, For everyone who missed the showing of "Prime Minister' - a film about the extraordinary term of Jacinda Adern's leadership of New Zealand - at the NZIFF, Rongotai Labour is pleased to secure a showing to help to raise funds for the 2026 election campaign.
This film chronicles Jacinda Adern's tenure as Prime Minister and provides an insight into both the political and personal challenges Jacinda faced during those six years. The inclusion of considerable footage from Jacinda's partner Clarke Gayford provides a deeply personal view of life as the Prime Minister in very challenging times.
(Los Angeles Times review) 'Prime Minister' is not interested in wrangling, dealing and lawmaking, or even the nuts and bolts or her progressive views. .. But in the fleet, pacey manner of the editing, toggling between private and public moments with highlight-reel efficiency, the film is a stirring glimpse of top-down kindness as a winning leadership style.
label: Film & Media

description:
Native Plant Papermaking Kids Workshop, Native Plant Papermaking Kids Workshop
Do you know a child who loves craft and making a splash? Join us for a fun family papermaking session!

We’ll be getting our hands wet as we explore the creative world of handmade paper using native harakeke (NZ flax) pulp. You will start off learning the simple skills of how to form a sheet of paper from wet pulp, then develop these skills by making different shapes and sizes, such as sheets, cards, envelopes, and ornaments. Express your own flair by experimenting with bits and pieces to add different colours and textures to your creations.

This workshop is designed for kids and accompanying adults to enjoy together. Adults are expected to assist hands-on and join the fun. Ages 5 and up.

description:
Newlands Tamariki Playcentre Open Week, If you have tamariki aged 0-6, you’re invited to your local centre during Playcentre Open Week to experience early childhood education with a difference.

Come along for a free visit and support your tamariki to learn through play, while you meet other whānau in your community. From sand and water play, arts and music, to outdoor and messy play, there will be a range of resources and experiences on offer.

With over 400 centres across Aotearoa there is one near you. You get three free visits before enrolling, so why not try a few centres in your community to see what suits you best?

Make a booking at newlandstamariki@playcentre.org.nz or 04 478 8470 (phone attended during session hours only)

description:
Kāpiti Run for Youth 2026, Kāpiti Run for Youth 2026
We’ve checked the tide timetable – Anchor your calendar now to take part in the 2026 Web Genius Kāpiti Run for Youth on Sunday 29 March 2026 – Raising funds for rangatahi in Kāpiti since 2011 while having fun strolling or running along the beautiful Kāpiti coastline. Kāpiti Run for Youth is a lively, family-friendly event focused on fostering community spirit and supporting organisations that encourage and uplift local young people. RAIN or SHINE, get ready to have fun!

We know Kāpiti Run for Youth helps to support amazing community work done by local fundraising partners. We have 13 incredible fundraising partners you can choose to support and raise funds for. We are very proud of them all and the work they do to uplift the youth of Kāpiti. Each partner brings something unique to the table, from providing essential resources and mentorship to creating spaces where young people can thrive. By supporting rangatahi through education, creativity, employment, and well-being initiatives, they ensure our youth are not just supported but empowered to reach their full potential. Our partners are creating a brighter tomorrow for the young people of Kāpiti!

In the beginning Kāpiti Run for Youth was created by Web Genius as their way as a local business to ‘give back’ to the community so, more than a decade on we can proudly say the event is sustainable and is popular with all sorts, young and old, the fit and not so fit. Kāpiti Run for Youth has raised $280,003 for rangatahi since inception in 2011. In 2025 the event raised $25,531 which was remarkable.

Kāpiti Run for Youth will be open for sign up early in January 2026 >> https://www.kapitirunforyouth.co.nz/signup

At that time, we will be seeking individuals and teams to get together to walk or run from Paraparaumu Beach (Maclean Park) to Raumati Beach and back. For those choosing the 12km walk or run, they will do two circuits of the course.

Choose your adventure – a 6km or 12km run or walk along the beautiful Kāpiti coastline. Whether it's a leisurely stroll or a mad dash to be the first across the finish, you choose the event that suits you best, and which of our amazing fundraising partners you're going to raise funds for. On race day grab your dog and your mates and head down to the beach for fun, family and fitness. Registration takes place from 8.30am to 9.45am with a briefing at 9.45am and all walkers and runners starting together at 10am.

Once your profile is set-up online, let your family, friends and work mates know so they can sponsor your efforts. We encourage every participant to raise $20 through sponsorship instead of paying an entry fee. All entrants receive regular campaigns to motivate their sponsorship efforts along the way.

Kāpiti Run for Youth prides itself on being a sustainable, family-friendly event that is all about supporting each other and having fun. Join your community for a feel-good morning on the beach. Your fundraising makes a difference in the lives of our young people! BYO sunhat, sunscreen, and water on the day, and there are sponsored spot prizes, treats for the kids, certificates for participating and free Paekākāriki Mini Pops for everyone at the end.

Checkout our FAQs over on our website >> https://www.kapitirunforyouth.co.nz/faqs

Closer to the event, go to our website to sign up or sponsor someone that you know who is participating >>
https://www.kapitirunforyouth.co.nz/search

All registrations and sponsorship are handled securely and confidentially on the Kāpiti Run for Youth website that is powered by Raisley and supported by Stripe online payments.

---------------------------------------------

BUSINESS SPONSORSHIP
Platinum $1,000+, Gold $500, Silver $250, Bronze $125 is available for businesses who want to support the underlying work of this event and rangatahi youth of Kāpiti. In 2025 we were grateful to 58 local business sponsors to the value of $15,125 that can be viewed on our website >> https://www.kapitirunforyouth.co.nz/sponsors

Sponsorship for the 2026 campaign will open late in January 2026

---------------------------------------------

FUNDRAISING MODEL
We focus on returning as much money as we can back to the Kāpiti community to those working with rangatahi. All funds raised are split 70% to the official Fundraising Partner chosen by the participant at the time of registration and 30% is retained towards running and promotion of the event.

FUNDRAISING PARTNERS
Birthright Kāpiti, Challenge for Change Kāpiti, Kāpiti Basketball Association, Kāpiti College, Kāpiti Kindness Trust, Kāpiti Youth Support, No 49 Squadron Air Cadets Kāpiti, Ōtaki College, Paraparaumu College, The Shed Project Kāpiti, Whirlwind Kāpiti, Work Ready Kāpiti, ZEAL Kāpiti >>
https://www.kapitirunforyouth.co.nz/fundraising-partners

---------------------------------------------

WELLNESS UPDATE
We operate within the Event Sector Voluntary Code. Please don’t attend if you are feeling unwell.

REGISTRATION DISCLAIMER
Kāpiti Run for Youth carries comprehensive Public Liability event insurance for a period of 48 hours that includes set-up, pack-down and during the event. We maintain an Accident & Incident Register at the Registration Gazebo and local GP, Paraparaumu Medical Centre, handle any medical emergency on the day of the event. We dial 111 if there is an incident beyond their resources.

We remind participants to take self-responsibility and those they are with when on the beach course and to alert officials as needed. It is important to listen to all instructions given on the day of the event at the pre-course briefing, and to report any incidents however minor they may seem. To report an incident, dial 027 244 9585.

PHOTOGRAPHY DISCLAIMER
Kāpiti Run for Youth reserves the right to use any image captured by our official photographer for promotional purposes in any media, in perpetuity without compensation, unless not consented.

---------------------------------------------

IN-KIND EVENT SPONSORS
24/7 Fitness, Beach FM, Captured By Friday Photography, Coffee to Die For, Kāpiti Business Projects, Kāpiti Chocolate Factory, Kāpiti Law, Kāpiti Party Hire, NZME, Paekākāriki Pops, Peter Jackson Plumbing, R-Line, Shoe Clinic, SignCraft Kāpiti, Speedy Signs Kāpiti-Porirua, Wellington Water Filters & Kāpiti Pure Water and Founder, Web Genius.

CAMPAIGN MANAGER:
Helene Judge | 027 244 9585

description:
Pinhole Photography - Three Day Creative Arts holiday programme, Did you know that any object that can be made light tight can be turned into a camera? Come along to this three-day workshop and choose an object – it could be a tea pot, a book, a coffee jar – to turn into a pinhole camera to then create black and white photographs with.

We’ll work in the darkroom and explore the process of loading your camera with silver gelatin paper, before making exposures in the garden around the historic Inverlochy house, testing different angles and perspectives. We’ll then return to the darkroom to develop your photographic negative, and print it as a positive. You’ll leave the course with a series of atmospheric pinhole photographs, having experienced the magic of hands-on darkroom printing.

Bring a water bottle and morning tea. Recommended age for this course is tweens & teens ages 10 and above.

Monday - Wednesday, 22 - 24 September, 10 am - 1 pm daily.

This workshop is part of Inverlochy Art School's September School Holiday Programme. For more teen & tween workshops including pottery, jewellery making, animation and sewing head to the 'Tamariki and Teens' section of our website.
label: Family Friendly

description:
Pavilion Open Day – Celebrate Spring with Us!, Pavilion Open Day – Celebrate Spring with Us!
Wednesday 24 September 2025, 10am – 2pm
Discovery Garden, Wellington Botanic Garden
Free
These September school holidays, welcome the season of new life and bright colours at our family-friendly Pavilion Open Day. Tamariki can explore the garden’s spring magic through self-guided, hands-on activities designed to spark curiosity and connection.
Activities include:
• Nature’s Colours Art Table – Create your own “spring colour” bookmark using petals, leaves, and other natural treasures.
• Spring Scavenger Hunt – Follow clues to spot signs of the season: sweet-scented flowers, fresh buds, busy birds and more.
• Spring Reading Nook – Relax on the grass mat with tree-stump cushions and enjoy a basket of spring-themed books.
• Bird’s Nest Discovery Table – Get up close to real nests (ethically sourced), soft bird puppets, and natural playdough to shape “eggs” and match them to their native bird owners.
Perfect for children aged 4–12 and their whānau. Dress for a day outdoors and celebrate te kōanga—the vibrant season of growth!
We’ll see you soon in the Discovery Garden, Wellington Botanic Garden!
label: Family Friendly

description:
Wesley Huff | Leaders Lunch | Wellington, Wesley Huff | Leaders Lunch | Wellington
This September Wesley Huff is joining Thinking Matters for the Truth Matters Tour in Dunedin, Christchurch, Wellington and full-day Conference in Auckland.

While in Wellington, he will be doing his only Christian Leaders Lunch.

Proceedings
Doors will open 11:15 am
11:30 am - the event will begin with a short powhiri/mihi whakatau
11:50 am - Kai
12:20 pm - Wes will present his talk and do q and a
1:30 pm - Conclusion of event
About Wesley Huff
Wesley Huff was born in Multan, Pakistan, and spent a portion of his childhood in the Middle East. After being diagnosed with a rare neurological condition at the age of eleven that left him paralyzed from the waist down, Wes experienced a miraculous recovery for which the doctors themselves had no medical explanation. This experience, along with a great deal of study and soul searching in his later teen years, solidified his interest in faith and in engaging the beliefs and worldview perspectives of others. He spent his high school years in Northern Ontario and currently lives in Toronto, Canada, with his wife and three children.

Wesley is currently the Central Canada Director for Apologetics Canada and has been a guest on a variety of public platforms, from The Joe Rogan Experience and Piers Morgan Uncensored, to Apologia Radio and Daily Dose of Wisdom. He has participated in numerous public dialogues, debates, and interfaith events on issues of belief and religion globally.

He holds a BA in sociology from York University, a Masters of Theological Studies from Tyndale University, and is currently doing a PhD in New Testament at the University of Toronto’s Wycliffe College.
label: Religion & Spirituality

description:
Café Scientifique - Space: What Is Our Place In the Cosmos?, Join us for a new Café Scientifique series hosted by Pūtaiao ki te Pāpori—School of Science in Society.

At this first event in September, astrophysicist Dr Yvette Perrott and novelist Dr Tim Corballis will discuss the evolving picture physics gives us about the nature of the universe, and the ways people find their place in it.

Café Scientifique is a place where, for the price of a cup of coffee or a glass of wine, anyone can come to explore the latest ideas in science and technology in a relaxed, friendly environment.

The evening will start with a short introduction from the speakers, followed by a question-and-answer conversation.

Doors open at 5.30 pm, talks begin at 6 pm. All welcome—free entry, nibbles provided.

Please note: anyone under the age of 18 must be accompanied by a parent or legal guardian.
For further information, please contact scienceinsociety@vuw.ac.nz.
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
He Kura Toi Tangata: Gold Card Tour, Te Waka Huia Wellington Museum invites our golden folk to experience an intimate, guided tour of photography exhibition He Kura Toi Tangata: 50 Years of the Waitangi Tribunal, 1975-2025.
The tour will continue throughout the museum, weaving through Wellington stories and taonga currently on display.
After the tour, we’ll sit down for a chat and a warm cuppa in the old Harbour Board room, with a little sweet something to finish off the afternoon.
This tour is part of the Takurua Hauora: Winter Wellness event series developed by Te Waka Huia Wellington Museum and is presented in collaboration with our programme partner Kāhui Legal.
Tickets are limited. Booking is essential.
Note: International visitor admissions are not included.

Sunday 24 August | 10:30am–12pm
$5 for SuperGold Card holders

Book online or over the phone on: 04 472 8904

label: Arts & Theatre

description:
Beginner Latte Art Class - Learn to Pour with The Hangar Crew, Learn how to pour beautiful latte art in this fun, hands-on beginner class with a skilled barista at The Hangar
Want to learn how to pour silky hearts and symmetrical tulips? Whether you're a coffee lover, a home barista, or just curious, this beginner Latte Art Class is for you!
Led by one of our skilled baristas at The Hangar, this hands-on workshop will take you through the fundamentals of milk steaming and latte art in clear, in-depth steps. You'll learn how to texture milk properly and pour a range of basic designs with confidence.
No experience needed
All equipment and milk provided
Hands-on, small group format
Date: Thursday, 4th of Sepember
Time: 17:00
Cost: $200 per person
Very limited spots, book now!
This class is beginner-friendly but packed with insight, perfect for anyone looking to build serious confidence on the steam wand and improve their latte art game.
Accessibility: The Hangar is wheelchair accessible and has gender-neutral bathrooms.
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Playcentre Open Week, If you have tamariki aged 0-6, you’re invited to your local centre during Playcentre Open Week to experience early childhood education with a difference.

Come along for a free visit and support your tamariki to learn through play, while you meet
other whānau in your community. From sand and water play, arts and music, to outdoor and messy play, there will be a range of resources and experiences on offer.

With over 400 centres across Aotearoa there is one near you. You get three free visits before enrolling, so why not try a few centres in your community to see what suits you.

To make a booking at Kelburn Playcentre please email kelburn@playcentre.org.nz
label: Family Friendly

description:
Bunnings Petone - Fathers day, Bunnings Petone - Fathers day
🎨✨ FREE Face Painting at Bunnings Petone! ✨🎨 Join us this Thursday, 4th September, between 5–7pm for a magical evening of fun!

🖌️ Free face painting, Plus loads of other exciting activities for the whole family!

Bring the kids, bring your smiles, and let the fun begin! 📍 Bunnings Petone — we’ll be bringing the sparkle!
label: Family Friendly

description:
Pocket Police Pups, 4 - 6 years
$5 per child
Bookings required

Do you enjoy creating things? Come in and make dog finger puppets. Choose your dog’s name, what they will look like and take them home with you. Programme includes use of glue, patience, and fun.

Book at museum reception:
Phone: (04) 238 3141
Email museum@police.govt.nz

Note: Limited parking at the Museum only, you may need to park on Papakōwhai Road.
label: Family Friendly

description:
Puppet Show: Once In a Full Moon, Be captivated these school holidays the gorgeous puppet show “Once in a full moon” performed by Anna Bailey of String Bean Puppets.
Deep in the bush a lonely kiwi looks up at the sky and mistakes the full moon for a giant egg. Can kiwis fly? Can moons fall from the sky? Can wishes come true? This magical string puppet adventure that introduces the audience to an intimate encounter with a few of Aotearoa New Zealand's special native creatures.
This show will be held in the Visitor Centre Foyer and is suitable for all ages, normal admission to the sanctuary applies. Overflow parking is available on Birdwood Street.
label: Family Friendly

description:
Royal New Zealand Ballet Presents Whanau Day at Te Papa, The RNZB comes to Te Papa for our annual day of fun for all ages. You’ll have the chance to peek behind the scenes of our exciting production of The Nutcracker and enjoy an action-packed day of activities with your national ballet company.

Bring your friends and whānau and enjoy dance workshops for children (including sessions for pre-schoolers), experience the magic of story-time, get colourful with face paint and crafty with ballet-themed activities. There will be something for everyone – see you there!


This is a free event, but registration is required for dance workshops.
label: Family Friendly

description:
SOLD OUT Fairy Potion Garden: An Enchanted Workshop, SOLD OUT Fairy Potion Garden: An Enchanted Workshop
Please join the waitlist for free, and we’ll be in touch if another session is added or if there are any cancellations.

About this Event

Please join the waitlist, and we’ll be in touch if another session is added or if there are any cancellations.
Joining the waitlist is FREE. The $35 shown is the ticket price if more spots become available.
Be sure to check out our other event listings while you’re here too!

SOLD OUT- Fairy Potion Garden: An Enchanted Workshop (1.5 hours)
Step into the enchanted fairy grove for a magical potion-making adventure! Led by a whimsical fairy guide, this hands-on workshop invites young potion crafters (ages 5+) to mix glittery brews, stir up flowery scents, and create their own take-home fairy potions. 🧚‍♀️✨
This 1.5-hour experience is full of sparkly fun, gentle storytelling and a sprinkle of mischief — with fizzy surprises, sweet smells, and lots of giggles.
Includes: 🌸 Potion making with a fairy host 🌼 Take-home fairy potion bottle 🧚‍♀️ Enchanting stories and magical games ✨ Perfect for kids aged 5 and up
A fluttery, fun-filled time for every little fairy and forest friend! 🌿💫

Please note that we are not registered childcare providers, which means an adult responsible for each child must remain on the premises. The venue is also a café restaurant with other areas where parents can chill while the workshop is running.
label: Family Friendly

description:
Over and Out, Created and performed by Jackson Burling.

"NEVER become a truck driver!" - A young Jackson Burling took that advice, avoiding the fork in the road, but now, after a long and gruelling two year slog in the arts industry he must confront that age old question: "why not, Dad?" - and take us along for the ride. In Over and Out, premiering at the 2025 TAHI Festival, Burling brings a real interview, a big character, and even bigger questions to the stage.

One actor. 50 minutes. Countless emotional potholes. Along the way, we get a rare look into the gritty, heartfelt, and often-overlooked life of one of Aotearoa’s essential workers: the truck driver. Is the open road calling — or is the stage his true destination? Buckle up. This is verbatim theatre with serious mileage.

Audience Care: Contains coarse language and mature themes.
label: Arts & Theatre

Theme: Lego!!
The St B’s Holiday Club is truly a fun time, with excellent facilities, a high adult-child ratio, hands-on crafts and creativity, music and jump jam, supportive small groups, games, challenges and movies.

description:
Street Dance Foundations with Shifting Centre at Māoriland, Manu Wairere is a school holiday programme at the Māoriland Hub in Ōtaki, designed to ignite the creative potential of tamariki and rangatahi Māori aged 5–18.

Rangatahi are invited to join Shifting Centre, a Wellington-based artist collective, for a 3-day Street Dance Foundations Workshop.

Participants will explore the foundations of street dance through cypher and Talanoa, building confidence, creativity, and connection.

The workshop will conclude with a performance for whānau and friends.
label: Family Friendly

description:
Take A Kid Tramping - Maketawa Hut Overnight, Family tramping.
Take a Kid Tramping Trip for our kids with extra stamina and ability to carry an overnight pack, this one has a lot of climbing. We will head up the translator track from North Egmont, turn off and follow the ridge down to the hut. The next day we will return via the Makatawa track down through the bush and across a few streams.
All participants must be equipped for tramping in alpine conditions. Overnight tramping equipment required.
Children must be accompanied by a parent or caregiver approved by their guardian.
Shared transport costs apply, unless own transport is provided.
$10 per adult passenger, kids or own car free + hut fee.
Hut Tickets or annual pass required.
If interested, please register by Thursday 11 September:
Jo-anne Mowat | takt@nptc.org.nz
label: Family Friendly

description:
Wairarapa Cinematheque presents RUN LOLA RUN (1998), Welcome to the Wairarapa Cinematheque
Film lovers in the Wairarapa have a new home for cinema. The Wairarapa Cinematheque launches in 2025 with a curated programme of classics, contemporary gems, and cult favourites — films you rarely get to see on the big screen.
Run Lola Run – One Night Only Screening | Wairarapa Cinematheque
Get ready for a high-octane cinematic thrill ride! Run Lola Run (1998) is a German cult classic that races through fate, love, and chance in a way you’ve never experienced. With its kinetic energy, unforgettable soundtrack, and inventive storytelling, this is a film best seen on the big screen.
📅 Date & Time: Sunday 30 November, 7:30pm
📍 Location: Regent 3 Cinemas, Masterton
Tickets:
If you purchased a Three Movie Membership on Opening Night, you’re covered — just present your card at the door.
Single tickets are $15 each, available via Humanitix or cash sales at the door on movie night.
Join us at the Wairarapa Cinematheque for a one-night-only celebration of film, artistry, and community. Don’t miss this unforgettable cinematic experience!
Join us in celebrating film, artistry, and community in the Wairarapa.
label: Film & Media

description:
Try Something New - Build, Paint, Play - School Holidays, School Holidays are a great if you have always wanted to get into the Warhammer hobby or if you are you looking to Try something new & want help with your next activity on your Warhammer journey.
It's also great if you want to improve your hobby skills.
Below you will find a few of the many Free hobby lessons we run at Warhammer Wellington
Introductory demonstrations: pick between a free introductory Stormcast or Space Marine model and then you can learn to build, paint and play a game with it.
Warhammer Build, Paint, Play Workshops are between 15min - 45mins
Learn to Build:
Learn how to build your miniatures & build your first model or a Free Miniature of the Month.
Learn to Paint:
Learn how to use Base, Shade, Layers, Contrast & Technical paints.
Learn to Play:
Learn more about the rules of your favorite game or try out a
new game.
All great ways to do the next step in your hobby journey while also getting your Battle Honours activities stamped off so remember to bring your activity book with you when you visit!
New to the Warhammer hobby & want to discover more about collecting, building, painting, playing Warhammer?
Drop in and have a chat with us about grabbing a Free Battle Honours booklet.
No need to book, just drop in or give us a call 04 471 098 to find out more
label: Family Friendly

description:
Toi Māori ki te ao atua with Raukawa Kiri, Manu Wairere is a school holiday programme at the Māoriland Hub in Ōtaki, designed to ignite the creative potential of tamariki and rangatahi Māori aged 5–18.

As part of this programme, local artist Raukawa Kiri will lead a 2-day arts workshop exploring the world of atua through Toi Māori. Participants will create artworks inspired by whakapapa, mana motuhake, and Te Ao Māori perspectives.

Children must be within arm's reach of an adult (a person over 16 years old).
label: Family Friendly

description:
The Pantoloons: Cinderella, Glass slippers, royal balls, and a Fairy Godmother who’s still on her learner’s licence, what could possibly go wrong?

Prince Percy is hopelessly charming (emphasis on hopeless), the Queen is busy approving new royal wave techniques (it’s very hard work being a Queen!), the step-sisters are causing chaos in couture, and Buttons has big dreams!

Will true friendship win over fairy-tale romance? Will Buttons dreams come true? And who is behind the kingdom’s mysterious gossip vlog? Packed with music, mischief, and magical mayhem, this is Cinderella with a twist, a tune, and a whole lot of sparkle! Step into a spellbinding world of wonder where dreams shimmer, magic floats on the breeze, and anything is possible… but only until the clock strikes twelve!

REVIEWS FOR RED RIDING HOOD

“You guys were amazing, thank you so much. Me and the kids had an amazing time. We can’t wait for the next holidays t come see you again.”

“My kids had a blast! My little man was in hysterics at Mr Moa.”

“Love everything that you do and each time gets better and better.”



SEATING LAYOUT: LARGE TIERED SEATING BLOCK. For accessibility seating information and wheelchair space bookings please email events@cdc.govt.nz or call 06 379 4081 during office hours.
label: Family Friendly

description:
Wellington Marine Life VR Experience, Dive beneath the surface and explore Wellington’s Blue Belt - no snorkel required!

Using virtual reality headsets, take a few minutes these school holidays to see the underwater world through the eyes of a scuba diver: swim through the deep reefs of Kapiti Island, be surrounded by schools of fish at Whitireia Park, glide through the lush marine forests of Taputeranga Marine Reserve, and explore a shipwreck! Expect close encounters with octopus, vibrant sea life and even a cute shark with the team from Explore Your Coast!

This free, drop-in event is suitable for the whole family and will be held in the Zealandia Visitor Centre Foyer. Regular admission fees to the sanctuary apply and overflow carparking is available at Birdwood Street during the busy school holiday period.

To learn more about our local underwater forests visit Explore Your Coast at https://exploreyourcoast.co.nz/
label: Family Friendly

description:
Costume Showcase 2025, Costume Showcase 2025
The Toi Whakaari graduating costumiers bring their creations to life in our 2025 Costume Showcase.

description:
DJ HYBRID (UK) - Labour Sunday Day Party, Labour Sunday Day Party ft. DJ HYBRID (UK)
+ Support from BAEOLI, BPM RADIO b2b YUNG MO, CERBERUS, YOUNG GHO$T, FE b2b GOS, FRONTA b2b INTEC & SOUNDED
Powered by Breakaway Soundsystem
Ghost Media, Rhythm Output and Full Time Senders are joining forces for a massive day of dnb & jungle this Labour Sunday
We had so much fun hosting DJ Hybrid last year that we decided to bring him back for round 2!
A true legend of the scene, DJ Hybrid has been peddling the craft for over 20 years, with releases on some Donny labels such as Jungle Cakes, Liondub and Serial Killaz, as well as his own Audio Addict imprint. His sound seamlessly straddles drum n bass and jungle, with a rave-ready style that is both nostalgic and forward thinking.
On support we have pulled out the dream team, with a stacked lineup of representatives from all the crews and a range of local selectors. Things are gonna run from early til late for this one, so prepare for a shift.
Extra special thanks to Breakaway who have agreed to take their soundsystem off the rave bus and give it a run at The Garden Hotel. With a similar build to the Banshee system, expect things to get loud and deep!
$15 early birds are on sale from Humanitix - secure yours now and prepare for a full day of rolling beats and massive vibes.

description:
Journey into Om, Yoga without mantra is a bit like cake without the icing !
By now we all know that everything essentially is vibration. Yoga knew this 1000's of years ago, that is why sound is the first tool of Yoga.
Learn about the pranavah mantra ( om) as it relates to your Yoga Practice.
In this 2-hour workshop, you will understand the traditional and respectful way to use this sacred sound: both theoretically and practically.
We will draw on the ancient texts of Yoga as our point of reference.
The use of a mantra is a powerful tool for healing, emotional and mental clarity, and spiritual development. You will be guided in a variety of accessible practices to experience the effects of this mantra.
This workshop can open new dimensions to your practice, or it is also a great way to start on the Yoga Journey.
I teach from the Viniyoga tradition of Krishnamacharya, where mantra is used as an integral aspect of Yoga, whether it be asana, pranayama, or meditation.
This workshop will be nourishing to all the dimensions -heart, mind, and body.
You do not need to be a singer at all-just be willing to have a go at making a sound, even in your head if out loud feels too weird.

description:
A Celtic Christmas by A Taste of Ireland - Wellington, A Celtic Christmas by A Taste of Ireland - Wellington
“Jingle Jigs, Reels a Treat.”
Ken Longworth – The Newcastle Herald

Direct from its Off-Broadway season, A Taste of Ireland - The Irish Music & Dance Sensation, presents its holiday spectacular, A Celtic Christmas. Prepare to be enchanted with some of the world’s finest Irish dancers and musicians bringing the spirit of Christmas to life, in a show that will make you laugh, cry, and sing into the night.

After captivating audiences across the USA and around the world, A Celtic Christmas by A Taste of Ireland returns to New Zealand this festive season following a highly successful 2022 tour. Experience the magic as world-class performers blend melodic folk mash-ups, acapella tap battles, and heartwarming storytelling in one truly unforgettable performance.

Featuring former World Irish dance champions and stars from Lord of the Dance and Riverdance, A Celtic Christmas delivers a holiday spectacular packed with Irish wit, traditional tunes and heartfelt ballads, alongside all your favorite carols. The show’s exciting mix of electrifying rhythms and extraordinary talent promises an evening brimming with Irish charm and enthralling entertainment, all in one powerhouse event.

Immerse yourself in a traditional Celtic landscape and let the magic of an Irish Christmas transport you to a world filled with excitement and wonder, where vibrant music and dance embody the heartbeat of the festive season.

With over one hundred and fifty 5-star Facebook reviews and over 150,000 followers, A Celtic Christmas by A Taste of Ireland promises 100% live singing and dancing as it bridges the gap between energetic folk music, Irish dance, and modern tap styles.

Don’t miss your chance to see this magical show as it tours New Zealand for a strictly limited season. Get your tickets now before they sell out.

**musical instruments are subject to change from performance to performance

Artsplash: Choir, ArtSplash is a week-long festival, held every two years, that celebrates tāmariki and rangatahi experiencing performance on the big stage in dance and choir concerts. This year, we have two separate groups performing – one at ArtSplash and the other at DanceSplash.
Whaea Emilee and Mrs Skippers have an amazing Choir group training to perform on Monday 25 August at the 5pm show, held at the Michael Fowler Centre.
This group will be heading into town by 8:15am and with an action-packed day planned, will stay in town until their 5pm performance.
Following the show, our students will be ready to head home with their spectator parents. Watch this space for more details and how you can help.

description:
BEN WILCOCK AND THE JELLY ROLLS, Ben Wilcock and The Jelly Rolls have been a mainstay on the Aotearoa jazz scene for the last 15 years. Their two studio albums are a collection of piano trio jazz, with the pervasive pianistic influences of Erroll Garner, Fats Waller, Oscar Peterson and Ahmad Jamal.
They have toured New Zealand extensively and performed internationally, including a sold-out performance at The Edinburgh Jazz Festival in 2019. Along with unique interpretations of jazz piano standards, the trio's repertoire includes original material from Wilcock's recently released album The River Tethys, as well as the solo piano album Goodnight T.V.

description:
Aurora Distillery Gin Experience, Create, make and take home your own gin with us at our Gin Experience sessions at our beautiful Wairarapa site, just 10 minutes from Martinborough. Our experienced distillery staff are on hand throughout to guide you through the process and give as much or as little advice as you want. We have hundreds of satisfied customers who have made some really exciting gins.

You’ll begin by foraging in the distillery gardens then we move to the gin-making room to learn about the gin making process and the ingredients involved. You’ll sample loads of botanicals then you will choose what you want to put in your very own gin recipe. After weighing out your recipe, you’ll move to your very own still and begin distilling!

While your gin is distilling, we’ll do a gin tasting of some of our own Arrival brand gins and some surprises from our other spirits.

At the end of the session you’ll bottle and seal your own 500ml bottle of gin to take home!

Please note each Experience attendee must have their own ticket. To ensure all participants have a great time and get our full attention we cannot accept spectators.

description:
Bookshop Day 2025, Mark your calendars, Bookshop Day takes place on Saturday 11 October! Bookshop Day is a one-day nationwide celebration of independent bookstores, highlighting the cultural importance of books and bookshops, and the people that bring the two together, our amazing booksellers.
This year marks 10 years of Bookshop Day in Aotearoa – that’s 10 years of dress-up competitions, live music, storytimes, regional bookshop hops, author readings, spot prizes, teddy bear sleepovers, giveaways, arts and crafts, scavenger hunts, delicious baked goods, and many, many more activities and offerings!
Bookshop Day is run by the Booksellers Association of New Zealand to encourage book lovers, like you, to celebrate your local bookshop.
Head to our website to explore our Bookshop Day event calendar and see what your local bookshop has planned this year: https://www.booksellers.co.nz/bookshop-day-2025-events

description:
Men's Group Tuesday 7 Oct, To join this community, and book your Tuesdays - please sign up here first, and we will email you the event access code. (our venue address will be emailed with your ticket).

This is a space for men to talk honestly, listen deeply, and figure some things out together. It’s not about having it all sorted. You don’t need to be a certain type of guy. Just show up as you are, with no pressure to speak or share.
Open group: new faces are welcome
Flexible: book to come when it suits you. Each Tuesday is a new event. Most will try for fortnightly.
Small groups: 8 men + 2 experienced hosts
Inclusive: all ages, backgrounds and identities (18+)
It's about connection and showing up, instead of going it alone. It makes time for meeting our various challenges, while learning and growing us into better friends, partners, dads, sons and humans. 
It isn’t a boys or bros club, therapy or a self-help seminar, religious or new-age. No fixing, preaching, or pressure. It’s not a crisis service or a substitute for professional care. The sign-up form explains this in more detail.
You can expect to:
Practice listening and learn communication skills for life
Discover greater integrity and self-accountability
Be supported in building your emotional intelligence
Become a part of a hearty and diverse community
Have a good time - it’s often uplifting and inspiring.
Joseph and your team of hosts have all been in regular men's groups for many years. The group sometimes offers simple and proven inquiries that draw on NVC, MBSR, active listening, gratitude and more.

description:
Carterton Daffodil Festival 2025, Carterton Daffodil Festival 2025
The Carterton Daffodil Festival is back for 2025!

Iconic daffodil field | Heritage train | High Street markets | Street performers | WAI ART SHOW | Library crafts + MORE... Here's a snippet of what's in store:

Your Daffodil Flyer experience (that's the train between Carterton to Masterton) has been revamped with new one-way options! Book you seat now: https://steaminc.org.nz/book-train-trip/daffodil-festival-flyer/

Wander through the golden daffodils at Middle Run. Access is by free bus only – no private vehicles permitted. Pick-your-own, bunches are $5 with proceeds going to Plunket and Wellington Free Ambulance.

Enjoy music, dance, and live acts throughout the day. From main stage performances to roving entertainers, there’s something for the whole whānau.

Visit the Wai Art Show at the Events Centre and browse a wide variety of art by talented local artists. A must-see stop for art lovers and collectors.

This year, the Carterton Library will be open with simple crafts for kids, a display from the Wairarapa Herb Society, and a free talk from Aratoi about our collaborative POP-UP museum.

Te Wiki o Te Reo Māori also begins on September 14 - to celebrate we invite you to come in and browse our Māori Collection and pick up a flyer – listing 50 of our resources to help you on your te reo journey.

We can't wait to see you at one of Carterton's biggest and brightest days of the year!

Big thanks to our event sponsors; Carterton District Council, Stuff Wairarapa Times-Age, and TSC Traffic Management.

description:
Carterton Daffodil Festival 2025, Carterton Daffodil Festival 2025
The Carterton Daffodil Festival is back for 2025!

Iconic daffodil field | Heritage train | High Street markets | Street performers | WAI ART SHOW | Library crafts + MORE... Here's a snippet of what's in store:

Your Daffodil Flyer experience (that's the train between Carterton to Masterton) has been revamped with new one-way options! Book you seat now: https://steaminc.org.nz/book-train-trip/daffodil-festival-flyer/

Wander through the golden daffodils at Middle Run. Access is by free bus only – no private vehicles permitted. Pick-your-own, bunches are $5 with proceeds going to Plunket and Wellington Free Ambulance.

Enjoy music, dance, and live acts throughout the day. From main stage performances to roving entertainers, there’s something for the whole whānau.

Visit the Wai Art Show at the Events Centre and browse a wide variety of art by talented local artists. A must-see stop for art lovers and collectors.

This year, the Carterton Library will be open with simple crafts for kids, a display from the Wairarapa Herb Society, and a free talk from Aratoi about our collaborative POP-UP museum.

Te Wiki o Te Reo Māori also begins on September 14 - to celebrate we invite you to come in and browse our Māori Collection and pick up a flyer – listing 50 of our resources to help you on your te reo journey.

We can't wait to see you at one of Carterton's biggest and brightest days of the year!

Big thanks to our event sponsors; Carterton District Council, Stuff Wairarapa Times-Age, and TSC Traffic Management.

description:
Roll for Hope 2025, A tabletop roleplaying games event, all proceeds will go to Make-A-Wish. Please visit our website for more information on games and times - https://rollforhope.nz
With a range of games including Dungeons & Dragons, Savage Worlds, Pirate Borg, Paranoia, homegrown games, playtests, and more, there's sure to be something for everyone.
The doors will open at 9.30am, with the first session starting at 10am. There will be three sessions of games in a variety of systems and genres; 10am-1pm, 2-5pm, and 6.15-9.15pm, Book for anywhere between 1-3 sessions for $8 per session, with a 20% discount if you book all three.
A survey link will be emailed closer to the event for attendees to rank their game preference so that we can assign people to games, check spam if you don't receive the email.

description:
Crash Bandihoot + DJ Danger, Yes!! Welly party favourites Crash Bandihoot return to Petone for another epic Jazz Festival party! Last year tickets sold out and the vibe was awesome!

Crash Bandihoot are a colourful raucous New Orleans street style party brass band known for bringing the weekend carnival vibes. Expect soaring horns and driving grooves and rhythms from the group representing Aotearoa NZ in both Australia and Brazil.

Plus support from the amazing DJ Danger spinning an all vinyl set!

"A plague" - Destiny Church
"Blew the roof off!" - Wunderbar Lyttleton
"Big. Bad. Brass." - Performance Arcade
"You guys are NUTS. BEST GIG. EVER!!" - 5Tapped

See you there!

DJ Danger - 7pm
Crash Bandihoot - 8pm

description:
F45 Run Club, F45 Run Club
RUN CLUB� In preparation for the Kapiti Half Marathon on 9 November 2025,

we’ would love for you to join us for Sunday morning runs. Open to ALL. Meet at 7:15am at the studio (10 Manchester Street) for a warm-up, then we’ll hit the Kapiti Expressway for a 30-minute run. This is for all fitness levels and paces. We’ll run 15 minutes out and 15 minutes back. Some will run faster, others (like me) a little slower, but we’ll all finish together. We’ll be back at the studio for a cool-down around 8am, before no doubt a few of us head off for a well-earned coffee!

description:
ChoctoberFest, Porirua is the home of New Zealand’s favourite chocolate — Whittaker's. So it's only fitting it has a festival celebrating all things chocolate. During September and October, the city is serving up a range of tasty treats for ChoctoberFest, all featuring Whittaker’s chocolate.
More than 30 local businesses will be competing in the Whittaker’s Bake Off and Top of the Chocs. Head in to participating spots, and try unique chocolate drinks and amazing baked goods. You can then vote for your favourites.
Indulge your tastebuds and try special drinks such as a whipped white choc biscoff latte, or a coldbrew shot choc maltini. For a sweet snack, how about a molten embrace, kunafa chocolate croissant, or a banoffee flossy pie? There are plenty of options for all chocolate lovers, including vegan and gluten free items.
As well as voting for your favourite items, you can join the fan club, share reviews, and be in to win. Up for grabs are 100 Whittaker’s Peanut Slabs, an exclusive tour of the Whittaker’s factory, and ChoctoberFest vouchers for local cafes and bars.
The festival has been running since 2022, and is a highlight of the local hospitality scene.
label: Festivals

description:
Album Release | Oscar Lavën's Elegant Calamity Orchestra, After receiving glowing international reviews for his debut album ‘Questions in Red’, flamboyant saxophonist / multi-instrumentalist Oscar Lavën is excited to release another exciting album, drawing together a vibrant collection of all-star musicians from various backgrounds under one roof in thrilling new original music, drawing influence from early American swing, blues, classical music, spiritual jazz and 50’s bar-walking rock & roll saxophone.

Prepare to be swept into a surreal cinematic world by the Elegant Calamity Orchestra; strings, woodwinds, brass, virtuosic percussionists and a deep-digging rhythm section, combining kaleidoscopic orchestral colours with the dangerous spontaneity of a small group. A momentous album release not to be missed.

Part of the Wellington Jazz Festival 2025
label: Music & Concerts

description:
Daffodil Express 2025, Daffodil Express 2025
Carterton’s Daffodil Festival in the early Spring creates a great day out for the whole family. Why not travel there in style by a heritage train, let Steam Incorporated take the stress out of travel as you take the train to the Wairarapa. This year, our train has reduced capacity, so be sure to book in quickly!

Hauled by our heritage locomotives, take a glimpse into the bygone era of train travel as we clear the rush of Wellington, racing through the suburbs of Petone, Lower Hutt & Upper Hutt. After picking up the last of our passengers at Upper Hutt, we will race through the 8.8km long Rimutaka tunnel. This tunnel remains the longest in New Zealand with scheduled passenger trains, and has just been subjected to a full track relay for the first time since it was opened in 1955.

Passing through Featherston, we head east and navigate the rolling hills towards Carterton.

Arriving into Carterton, you'll have a few hours to disembark and go and explore Carterton's annual Daffodil Festival , before jumping on the train for the return journey home.

The Daffodil Fields and Festival
Located in the heart of the Wairarapa, Carterton’s popular Daffodil Festival offers an abundance of activities ranging from the famous Daffodil picking at Middlerun Farm, markets along High and Holloway Streets, the Big Wai Art sale in the events Centre, live music, and loads more family fun.

Shuttle buses will run from the town centre to the daffodil fields. There will be a lot of people for these buses, so please be patient. The bus transfer is free.

Here you can pick your own daffodils for $5 (Cash Preferred) that is a fundraiser for Wellington Free Ambulance and Whānau Āwhina Plunket, Wairarapa region. While stocks last!

The fields are not suitable for walkers or wheelchairs due to uneven grounds.

Prior booking is essential, this is an annual sell out event!

Fares
Adult (13+) - $125
Child (2-12yrs) - $90
Infant - Free

For more information & tickets, head to https://steaminc.org.nz/book-train-trip/daffodil-express/
label: Festivals

description:
The Epic Zombie Bar Tour - Wellington, The Epic Zombie Bar Tour - Wellington
WELLINGTON's BIGGEST ZOMBIE BAR TOUR!

Join 150+ party-goers in freaky costumes as we crawl through the best party bars in town

About this Event

THE EPIC ZOMBIE BAR TOUR!
Saturday 1st November

Wellington’s BIGGEST ZOMBIE Bar Tour
Prepare yourself for a spine-chilling night like no other! Get ready to experience the ultimate Halloween thrill with 150+ party-goers, all dressed in their freakiest, blood-curdling costumes, crawling through Wellington's best party bars. This event will leave you shaking in your boots while having the time of your (undead) life!
The night kicks off at Vinyl Bar, where you'll be transported to a haunted 1980s retro-themed Halloween drink experience that will have your hair standing on end. Then we creep up Courtenay Place to the Saint Diablo for a Mexican "Day of the Dead" fiesta that will have your soul howling for more. From there, we'll descend into the darkness of Shady Lady, where the scariest surprises lurk around every corner.
But it doesn’t end there! The ghostly tour continues with a visit to El Barrio for another sinister "Day of the Dead" celebration. Finally, brace yourself as we crawl to our final destination, Eva Pub, for Wellington's BIGGEST Halloween Party, where DJ DKAV and special guests will be delivering electrifying beats that will raise the dead!
This will be one wild, spooky night that no soul will forget. But beware, LIMITED TICKETS are available, and this eerie experience WILL SELL OUT.
Join us... if you dare.*Crawl Includes 1 House Drink & Food

description:
Dancesplash 2025, ArtSplash is a week-long festival, held every two years, that celebrates tāmariki and rangatahi experiencing performance on the big stage in dance and choir concerts. This year, we have two separate groups performing – one at ArtSplash and the other at DanceSplash.
Mrs Long and Mr Graff have a hard-working troupe of dancers training to perform on Thursday 28 August at the 5pm show, held at the Opera House.
This is a new venue for the show, what a treat! This group will be heading into town by 8:15am for the dress rehearsal, before returning to school to catch their breath. They’ll head back in together on the bus and will be ready to head home with their spectator parents at the conclusion of the show. Watch this space for more details and how you can help.
Tickets are now on sale. You can purchase them via the Ticketmaster website. NOTE: Due to limited seating and a high number of schools involved, there is a limit of TWO tickets per performer. Don’t miss out!
label: Festivals

description:
Make Some Noise - Choral Music That Matters, Supertonic is back with a programme of contemporary choral music that matters!

On the evening of Saturday 8 November, Supertonic will present Make Some Noise at the Lower Hutt Town Hall.

Make Some Noise highlights issues of social justice, including indigenous, women’s and civil rights and climate action. The programme is rich and varied, from Katerina Gimon’s arrangement of AURORA’s Apple Tree, a Norwegian pop song addressing the urgency of the global climate crisis, to Robert T. Gibson’s arrangement of the gospel standard This Little Light of Mine. Oliassa by Malika Tirolien utilises an invented language to invoke a call from the ancestors, while Alex Vollant titles their piece Auass meaning “child” in the Innu language to honour the generation of elders who survived the Residential Schools in Canada. The impact of sexual harassment and assault on women is highlighted in MILCK’s I Can’t Keep Quiet and Lillia Ruocco and Emmanuelle Ader’s Canzone rò curtiell’.

Closer to home, Make Some Noise features a set of waiata in teo reo Māori to highlight the importance of indigenous voices in Aotearoa New Zealand, including Ngoi Pēwhairangi’s Whakarongo. This waiata-ā-ringa incorporates Ngoi Pēwhairangi’s beliefs and methodology on teaching te reo Māori.

Led by Musical co-Director Virginie Pacheco, Supertonic offers Make Some Noise as an invitation to concert-goers to consider the causes that are important to them. In connecting with audiences through the striking and impactful works of the composers featured in this programme - by turns harmonious, raucous, gut-wrenching, resolute - the choir hopes to inspire those listening to make some noise in their own lives

description:
Diwali Festival of Lights 2025, Step into the vibrant world of India and South-East Asia at this year’s Diwali Festival of Lights.

Enjoy a lively event filled with music, dance, and cultural performances, plus fun activities for the whole whānau.
Explore Indian fashion and jewellery stalls, try your hand at henna and lantern-making, meet local community groups, and feast on delicious regional cuisine.
The night will wrap up with a fireworks display at approximately 8.50pm!

For up-to-date information, including wet weather updates, visit the Facebook event page via https://www.facebook.com/share/1BDZhDUXCG
label: Festivals

description:
Diwali Festival of Lights, Diwali Festival of Lights is an exciting cultural celebration with fun activities for the whole whānau . Experience the colours, tastes, and sounds of India and South-East Asia. TSB Arena and Shed 6 will host a variety of performances and plenty of activities to keep you entertained. Take part in henna painting and lantern-making. Feast on delicious regional cuisine, explore Indian fashion and jewellery, and meet local community groups. Most importantly, enjoy this important and joyous festival. 
At the end of the night, enjoy the fireworks show as the event goes out with a bang. The fireworks display will start at approximately 8:50pm on Wellington Harbour (weather dependent). 
Diwali is a significant annual festival that marks the triumph of light over darkness, good over evil, and knowledge over ignorance. It is celebrated by Hindus, Sikhs, and Jains in communities all over the world. It’s marked with candles, lanterns, and fireworks. It is also known as Deepavali and is one of India’s most widely-celebrated holidays.
label: Festivals

label: Government & Politics

description:
The Great Southern BioBlitz 2025, A bioblitz is all about searching for and recording all the species you can over a set time period.
Zealandia is one of the most biodiversity rich places in the motu(show English translation) and the perfect place to come searching for species over the long weekend. You may well find species that we have seldom seen, so this is fun for you and potentially invaluable information for our conservation team. It’s a great reason to go exploring some of the tracks you might not know well, or at all!
All you have to do is upload your observations of species to iNaturalist. It doesn’t have to be done during those four days. In fact, you’ll have a further 14 days to upload and identify all your observations made during the official period.
The Great Southern BioBlitz 2025 is run by a network of keen citizen scientists from across the globe.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Denniston - a place worth fighting for., The Denniston Plateau is one of Aotearoa's most unique landscapes and is rated by the Department of Conservation as a key ecologically valuable site. It is a unique ‘lost world’ ecosystem home to a remarkable array of life. A fast-track application to mine 20-million tonnes of coal in the area is expected to be filed this year.
Join us for an engaging session to:
Hear from experts about Denniston Plateau’s extraordinary biodiversity and ecology.
View a photo exhibition by West Coast photographer Neil Silverwood capturing the Plateau’s beauty.
Learn about the proposal to expand coal mining in the area
Wine, beer and appetisers are provided. You may be asked to show proof of identity upon arrival.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
FRUIT LOOP FESTIVAL, Fruit Loop Festival
Marlborough’s freshest music festival!
About the Festival
Fruit Loop Festival is Marlborough’s juiciest new summer gig! A full-blown celebration of music and dance, kicking off under the sun and well into the night. Think open-air energy - blending Marlborough's summer magic with a full-scale music festival. An insane line-up of DJs and live performers with production to match! From the first drop to the final track, it's where the beat hits harder and the drinks taste sweeter.
Fresh, wild, fierce - Fruit Loop is the party Marlborough has been waiting for.
The Line-Up
DICK JOHNSON: The heart of NZ’s electronic scene, Dick Johnson is a true house music heavyweight. With remixes for global icons like Fatboy Slim and Claude VonStroke, plus Kiwi favourites L.A.B and Tiki Taane, he’s spent over two decades electrifying dancefloors worldwide. A relentless force behind the decks - and music director for Synthony - Dick brings the fire every time.
SIN: Co-host of George FM Drive, Sin is plugged into the pulse of the dance scene and has quickly become a revered authority on all things electronica. She’s torn up stages at Rhythm & Vines, Homegrown, Hidden Valley, and international festivals from Fiji to the UK. With supports for legends like Fatboy Slim, Groove Armada, and Netsky, Sin brings high-energy house, techno, and ravey curveballs to every set.
KITA MEAN: Kita Mean is New Zealand’s award-winning drag superstar, known for her infectious charm, razor-sharp wit, and high-camp aesthetic. With a career spanning 15+ years across stages and screens worldwide, she’s wowed audiences from Aotearoa and Australia to London, Canada, the USA, and beyond. Winner of the very first RuPaul’s Drag Race Down Under and co-owner of the iconic Caluzzi Cabaret, Kita continues to dazzle with colourful looks, flawless mug, and hilarious timing. Quirky, kooky, kitsch, and quick - Kita Mean isn’t just a queen, she’s an experience.
PETE GREEN: Originally from the UK, Pete is part of the vinyl-digging collective Rare Specimens. His love for deep, worldly electronic sounds brings low-end warmth and an infectious energy to the dancefloor. Along the way, he’s supported artists such as Crazy P, Psychemagik, Audio Jack, and Christopher Tubbs, playing festivals and parties from Creamfields and Rhythm & Alps to Tempo Schmempo. Expect a set seasoned with Italo, ambient, and deep house flavours, dusted with disco, and finished with a splash of techno.
Event Details
Date: Saturday 28 March 2026
Time: 2pm - 10pm
Location: The Fancy Cow, Marlborough
R18 event - Photo identification will be required.
Return Bus Service:
Getting to and from the festival is easy with our return bus service. Pick-up points will include Redwoodtown Woolworths, Seymour Square, and Countdown Springlands. Purchase a return bus ticket when you nab your ticket.
A full timetable and bus information will be announced closer to the event.
Parking is strictly limited at the festival. Drop off recommended.
Tickets
Tickets are limited — don’t wait. Secure yours now!
Door sales may be available.
Have your ticket open and ready to be scanned at the gate.
Kaupapa
Fruit Loop is a safe, inclusive space where everyone belongs. If you can’t celebrate diversity, respect others, and bring good vibes, this festival isn’t for you.
Harassment or discrimination of any kind will not be tolerated. Anyone behaving this way will be removed.
Refunds and Cancellations
Fruit Loop Festival is a rain or shine event. The festival will proceed regardless of weather conditions, except in circumstances where safety is compromised or conditions make it impossible for the event to continue.
No refunds will be given for changes to the programme, line-up, or advertised performers.
Stay Connected
Follow us for line-up drops, updates and key event information: @fruitloopfestival on Instagram
label: Festivals

description:
Family Grave Day 2025 - Wellington, Family Grave Day 2025 - Wellington
The world’s biggest family-friendly rave just got haunted… and Wellington, we’re coming for YOU! 👻

This is not your average Halloween party – it’s a full-blown Halloween rave for the whole family, packed with banging beats, dazzling performers, and spooky surprises at every turn. Whether you’re a mini-monster or a grown-up ghoul, get ready for an afternoon of music, mayhem, and memories you’ll never forget. Costumes are highly encouraged – the more outrageous, the better!

Date & Time: Saturday 15th November, 1PM – 4PM
Location The Hunter Lounge

🎟 Tickets
First Release - SOLD OUT!
Second Release - ON SALE NOW

👉 https://megatix.com.au/events/FGDWELL25


👻 WHAT TO EXPECT:

🧛‍♀️ All-Ages Family Rave – Dress to impress in your spookiest costumes for maximum Halloween fun!

🏢 Prime City Venue – The Hunter Lounge is easy to get to with great parking and public transport links.

🎶 Club DJs & Performers – International DJs dropping trance, techno & nostalgic bangers, plus stilt walkers, jugglers, and spine-tingling roaming performers!

🔇 Silent Disco & Sensory Zone – Pop on your headphones and dance in spooky silence, or chill out in our sensory space.

🕷️ Spooky Interactive Fun – Inflatables, Halloween-themed games, arts & crafts, face painting, and more!

🍕 Frightfully Good Food – Delicious restaurant meals available onsite to keep the ghouls fed.

🥂 Adult Beverages Available – Enjoy a drink while the kids rave (responsibly, of course).

💀 Immersive Halloween Atmosphere – Expect haunted lighting, eerie decor, and special effects that’ll transport you to the other side.

🧙‍♀️ Giveaways & Surprises – Don’t miss your chance to rave beyond the grave… and win!

⚡ Spots are limited – secure your tickets before they vanish into the night! ⚡

NZ Professional To Paid Consultant In 30 Days, Wellington Professionals! Thinking about packaging your expertise into coaching/consulting programs in 2025? This free event is for you…

description:
NZ Mountain Film Festival 2025 - Awards Night, A collection of New Zealand-made mountain films - brought to you by the Vic Uni Tramping Club, Wellington Tramping and Mountaineering Club, and of course the New Zealand Mountain Film and Book Festival!

Awards Night: Thursday 25 Sep (doors open at 6:00pm, films start at 6:30pm):

- Footprints on Katmai (22 mins) Max Romey, USA. Following his grandmother's footsteps to one
of the most remote and bear-strewn beaches in Alaska, painter Max Romey discovers that an
ocean of problems is closer to home than he could have imagined. BEST FILM ON THE ENVIRONMENT
- Alone Across Gola (20 mins) Jude Kriwald, UK, NZ Premiere. Stranded in Liberia’s Gola
rainforest, filmmaker Jude Kriwald faces hunger, isolation, robbery and disappearing trails. A raw
tale of one man’s solo, self-filmed journey chasing a childhood dream. With only a bike and a
tent, Jude pushes the limits of survival and self-discovery. BEST ADVENTUROUS SPORTS & LIFESTYLES
- Zahir (36 mins) Julien Nadiras, Switzerland, subtitles. Katherine and Eline take on an iconic rock
route, accessing it by bike. Their all-eco ascent tests endurance, nerve, and friendship, with long
runouts and tiny holds pushing them to the edge.
- Body of a Line (10 mins) Henna Taylor, subtitles, USA. A cleverly animated short film that
morphs into real life as Madaleine undertakes an intimate and creative journey to climb a difficult
rock route, with original music and poetry. BEST SHORT FILM
- Trango (46 mins) Leo Hoorn, USA. After a two-year attempt, ski mountaineers ski the first
descent of the Great Trango Glacier. They navigate risk, grapple with grief, and face physical
danger as they push the limits of human experience. Unspoken trust and support within their
expedition team allows them to face the unimaginable together. GRAND PRIZE FILM

Total running time: 120 minutes + 15 minute intermission.

description:
Great Sounds Great Festival 2025, Eyegum Music Collective presents GREAT SOUNDS GREAT, a multi-venue music and arts festival taking over Pōneke's Cuba Street precinct for one night only on Saturday 6 September 2025. Showcasing 40 of Aotearoa's best artists across 10 neighbouring venues, this is one big party you shouldn't miss.

Eyegum has worked hard to curate a programme that is sure to offer something for everyone, from first time gig-goers to seasoned live music obsessives. The eclectic lineup includes perennial indie maestros The Bats, capital hometown heroes The Phoenix Foundation, hip hop superstar JessB, troubadour-turned-party starter Anthonie Tonnon, captivating genre-bender Reb Fountain, the incredible local-by-way-of-Naarm Jen Cloher, plus a selection of up-and-coming artists handpicked from Eyegum's Free Wednesday weekly showcase series, and everything in between. There will also be plenty more to be announced soon.

Excitingly for 2025, we will be adding three new venues: St Peter's on Willis, Flying Nun Records and 13 Garrett Street (sponsored by Radio Active), as well as a travelling electronic stage curated by Tonic Collective. This means more artists and music to experience in a variety of special and unique spaces throughout the night.

Ticket holders will receive a wristband that will give them access to each of the participating venues throughout the event. Information on how to pick up wristbands will be provided to ticket holders closer to the time.

Tickets are on sale now at eyegum.co.nz/great-sounds-great

When: from 4pm Saturday 6 September 2025
Where: San Fran, Meow, Valhalla, Rogue & Vagabond, Bedlam & Squalor, Hotel Bristol (2 stages), St Peter's on Willis, Flying Nun Records, 13 Garrett St

Who: The lineup will include Anthonie Tonnon, Baby Zionov, Bad Taste, BADTAB, Baeoli, Bathysphere, The Bats, By A Damn Sight, Cindy, Eveline Breaker, Goya, Half/Angel, Hans Pucket, Iris Little, Jazmine Mary, Jen Cloher, JessB, JHL, Jim Nothing, Jordan Hamel, Leah Dodd, LEAO, Louisa Nicklin, The Phoenix Foundation, Reb Fountain, Rebecca Hawkes, Shayne P Carter (solo), Sig Wilder & Friends, Sofia Machray, Space Bats, Attack!, The Spectre Collective: live-scored cinema, Star Time, plus more artists to be announced soon.

description:
Nature Journaling with Sandra Morris, Observe, draw, and write from nature. 9 November.

Reconnect with the natural world in this mindful workshop led by award-winning botanical artist and illustrator Sandra Morris. Set in the historic garden and visitor center of Nairn Street Cottage, you’ll learn how to observe, draw, and write from nature, whether for identification or simply for pleasure.

Nature journaling invites us to notice the intricate relationships between plant and creature, decay and growth, and the quiet beauty often missed in the rush of daily life. Through sketches, diagrams, poems, lists, or prose, you’ll discover your own way of recording the world around you.

All materials provided, however, please feel free to bring your own preferred drawing tools, such as watercolour pens, colour pencils and your own journal if you already have one underway.

Sunday 9 November, 10am-12:30pm
Tickets $65.00
Bookings essential

Sandra will also be doing an Introduction to Botanical Drawing and Plant Inks workshop on Saturday, 8 November. Make a weekend of it and book both to receive a $20 discount. On the booking details page, you’ll have the option to add a second workshop with Sandra Morris. When both are selected, the discount will be applied automatically.
