description:
James Nokise: One Night Rant | Wellington, James Nokise: One Night Rant | Wellington
Irreverent, incorrigible, and just ever so outraged, award-winning comedian James Nokise lets loose in Wellington for one night only!

Politicians, policies, preachers, and protests are all in the line of fire as Nokise brings his fast paced, semi-chaotic, always cathartic, blend of humour and hot takes back to NZ for a hilarious hour of big laughs and the occasional frustrated scream.

One Night Rant is political comedy at its sharpest. From parliament scandals to global chaos, Nokise rips into the news cycle, mixing big laughs with bite-sized truths. This is a one-hour comedy special designed for anyone who’s ever shouted at the TV, despaired at the headlines, or secretly enjoyed watching politicians squirm.


About James Nokise

A multi-talented comedian, playwright, columnist, podcaster, theatre maker, and social commentator, James Nokise is known for his fearless approach and his ability to give a voice to underrepresented issues.

Over the course of his illustrious career James has been nominated twice for the Billy T Award (2005, 2006) and the Fred Award for Best New Zealand Show (2013), which he subsequently took out in 2019 for his show God Damn Fancy Man. He won Best Male Comedian at the NZ Comedy Guild Awards (2013), Spirit of the Festival at the 2021 NZ Comedy Fest and the Topp Prize (2024). James was also the winner of best documentary at the 2025 NZ radio awards for his series The Last Voyage of the Rainbow Warrior, and winner of the Best International Podcast at the 2025 Asia Podcast Awards.

James has an extensive touring career, including over a decade of shows in the NZ International Comedy Festival and multiple Comedy Gala performances, as well as years on the international Fringe Festival circuit, performing successful seasons in Edinburgh, Perth, and New York.

description:
Not Your Nana's Craft Market - R18 Art and Craft Market, *Strictly R18*
Are you ready for a unique and thrilling experience? Look no further! We invite you to the most captivating event of the year - the Creepy-Cute, Witchy, Kinky, Sexy, LGBTQIA+ Friendly Alternative Art and Craft Market!

What to Expect
Get ready to immerse yourself in a world where art and craft meet the dark and mysterious. This market is not for the faint of heart! Here's what you can expect:
1. Creepy-Cute Delights: Explore a wide range of art and craft creations that blend the creepy and cute aesthetics. From adorable monsters to spooky dolls, you'll find something to tickle your fancy.
2. Witchy Wonders: Dive into the world of witchcraft and magic. Discover spellbinding artwork, mystical jewelry, and enchanting potions. Embrace your inner witch or warlock!
3. Kinky Curiosities: For those who enjoy a touch of kink, we have a selection of unique and provocative art and crafts, and kink wear. Explore the boundaries of sensuality and embrace your desires in a safe and inclusive environment.
4. Sexy Sensations: Indulge in the world of sensuality and erotic art. Discover captivating paintings, sculptures, and photography that celebrate the beauty of the human form. Embrace your sexuality with pride!
5. LGBTQIA+ Friendly: This market is a safe space for all members of the LGBTQIA+ community. Celebrate diversity and inclusivity as you explore the wide range of art and craft offerings.
6. Alternative Art and Craft: Step outside the mainstream and explore the alternative side of creativity. From gothic to steampunk, from punk to cyberpunk, you'll find a variety of unique and unconventional art and craft pieces.
Join Us!

Don't miss out on this extraordinary event! Mark your calendars and invite your friends. Get ready to be amazed, inspired, and maybe even a little bit spooked. See you at the Creepy-Cute, Witchy, Kinky, Sexy, LGBTQIA+ Friendly Alternative Art and Craft Market!
It definitely will NOT be your nana's market! See less

description:
Plant Sale, I have had great success with NZ and imported seed propagation this year so we have a wonderful range of plants ready to go in the ground now.
Some varieties are extremely limited due to the cost of the imported seed and the tiny amount of seeds per packet (only 5 in some cases).
We will be accepting preorders by messenger so get in quick if you don't want to miss out on these special plants.
Please note: Our garden will not be open during the plant sale. We aim to open in approximately 5 weeks but it depends how the tulips progress.
As other plants reach maturity we will make them available for sale on our open days. We have decided to have a pre season sale to make room for more beauties.
Abutilon - a range of mixed colours including peach, rose and lemon.
Dwarf Agapanthus - a fine leaved pale blue variety. Great for edging paths and beds. Will not take over.
Aubretia - Lavender trailing plant for rock walls and garden edges.
Arabis - White blooming Spring groundcover
Ajuga - Pink and purple varieties. Great November blooming groundcover for damp areas.
Aster - Early summer flowering variety in blue/lavender
Calamintha - new for us so I shall borrow the Chiltern seeds description. This is a most pleasant plant for your border or herb garden. Heavily scented with a fragrance described as pennyroyal-like, it is an erect perennial with small, somewhat hairy leaves. In summer it bears numerous whorled spikes of tiny blue flowers with long purple bracts. The herb can be used for flavouring. Flowers the first year from seed. 1½ft (45cm).
Campanula glomerata - deep purple
Cerastium - grey trailing leaves smothered in white blooms in Spring. (These have just been cut back)
Cerinthe - By popular demand. Technically an annual but a non invasive self sowing one so once its in your garden you'll have more each year. Glaucous foliage and interesting pendular purple blooms.
Dianthus - Grey leaves and red blooms
Erigeron multiradiatus - A beautiful evergreen groundcover with yellow centred purple/blue daisies from late spring.
Erysimum - a specialty for us as we love them so much. What's not to love? Front to mid border, semi shrubby evergreen perennial, glorious scented blooms and we have individual named colours.
Ivory, Purple bi-colour, Fire King, Vulcan, Ellen Willmott, Primrose, Ruby gem, Siberian allionii and the brand new Tangerine Titan.
Euphorbia - golden foam. Another newbie for us but we love the the chartreuse euphorbias add to the garden so we had to give it a go.
Euphorbia characias - the blue leaved evergreen semi shrubs with huge chartreuse heads that grace our garden every spring.
Geum - Yes, you guessed it, another favourite of ours. We have a good stock of the common types plus some more unusual ones.
Tall - Yellow, Red and Orange (Firestorm).
Dwarf - Deep orange/red, Lemon with hints of pink, blush (very pale pink) and the original geum rivale in a beautiful coppery peach.
Lunaria (Honesty). Two types available. Chedglow the purple leaf version that has taken Chelsea by storm the last couple of years. Variegata - the green leaves become edged in white in their second year before blooming with the typical mauve flowers.
Lysimachia nummularis - yellow creeping jenny. Great lime leaf trailing plant for part shady damp areas. One only.
Orlaya grandiflora - another favourite among designers. A self sowing annual that will provide weeks of beautiful white lacecap flowers. Perfect for filling in border spaces until the summer perennials fill in or to give a light airy feel to meadows and spring plantings. Seedlings will return year after year.
Pelargonium - Deep red
Pulmonaria - Raspberry splash
Romulea - small bulbs grow fine grassy leaves before erupting into a mass of deep rosy purple crocus type flowers in late spring.
Scabiosa - another specialty plant for us as they provide such amazing flower power all summer and autumn. They are not frost hardy but are perennial in sheltered spots for at least 3 years. Enjoy the flowers and at the end of the season collect several packets worth of seed to multiply your stock.
Named varieties available:
Snowmaiden - white, Black Knight - deep maroon, Beaujolias Bonnets - a gorgeous blend of pink, white and burgundy on the same flower, Burgundy beau - a new one this year, Salmon Queen - the most delicious shade of salmon pink. Pale yellow Fata morgana, and blue ones will be available later in the season.
Stachys officinalis - dark pink flowered evergreen groundcover. Perfect for the front of garden beds and rock gardens.
Sissyrinchium blue eyed grass. Low grassy leaves burst in to a mass of blue star shaped flowers in Spring.
Sedum mexicana - a bright lime evergreen succulent groundcover. Perfect for supporting bold tulips in spring and bright perennials in summer.
Sedum Mr Goodbud. A slightly pinker version than the well known Autumn joy.
Sparaxia - very special maroon flowers. Couple only.
Symphytum grandiflora - low-lying evergreen groundcover with medium sized leaves and stunning cream bell flowers all through spring. Excellent spreading plant for difficult to grow areas such as the shade of evergreen trees.
Urospermum - sown last spring and flowered for the first time in summer. Don't be put off by its dandelion looking leaves. This is a beauty with huge lemon flowers ( yes again like a dandelion but oh so much more beautiful). It has survived a wet winter in our gravel garden and also in soil. Definitely not a weed!
Violets - green leaf with white scented flowers and the later flowering purple leaved Viola labadorica with purple flowers.
label: Markets & Fairs

description:
Karanga taonga, karanga tangata, karanga whenua |Reversing Cultural Amnesia: Activating Māori Practice in Museums, In 1947, Māori leader, politician, and scholar Apirana Ngata spoke to his scholarly peers at the Polynesian Society, announcing his greatest desire to revive Māori culture as a living force within communities, not be relegated to dead exhibits in museums (Ramsden 1948, 85).
This lecture acknowledges the concerns of visionary leaders and champions of cultural practice and their activation within museums. Through her work as a Māori curator, writer, cultural practitioner and post-doctoral researcher, Awhina Tamarapa advocates for cultural restoration as a form of liberation in a museum context. In her research, Tamarapa is exploring strategies for the recovery and reclamation of taonga puoro (singing treasures) and karetao (animated storytellers) for new generations.
There are challenges regarding taonga held by overseas museums. Concepts such as keeping taonga warm, and mana taonga, recognises the connection and authority of descendants to their taonga, that underpin this work.
The focus on the reclamation of Indigenous practice has been bolstered by working with First Nations, Canada BC. Led by Professor Bryony Onciul, University of Exeter, UK, Tamarapa was privileged to be part of a research project “The Future of Indigenous Rights and Responsibilities: Ancestral governance, environmental stewardship, language revival, and cultural vibrancy” funded by the Arts and Humanities Research Council, UK.
_________
The Michael Volkerling Lecture series is a partnership event with the Museum and Heritage Studies programme at Te Herenga Waka | Victoria University of Wellington, National Services Te Paerangi and Te Papa Tongarewa. This annual public lecture series recognises the legacy of the late Dr Michael Volkerling who was one of the principal architects of New Zealand's cultural and creative sectors.

PREVIEW NIGHT - Light in the Square Art Expo, PREVIEW NIGHT - Light in the Square Art Expo
AN EXCLUSIVE FIRST LOOK

Be among the first to view the Annual Karanga Art Exhibition — a special evening for those ready to invest in meaningful, story-rich artwork.

This night is for serious collectors, supporters of local artists, or anyone who senses there’s something deeper behind the canvas.

Some artists are fundraising for mission trips and community outreach, so every purchase has the potential to make an impact beyond the gallery.

WHAT TO EXPECT

- Entry by donation (koha welcomed)
- Light snacks and refreshments provided
- Cash & carry – take your artwork home on the night
- Live collaborative artwork for silent auction
- Limited capacity – priority for those considering a purchase

Please RSVP by selecting “Going” to help with catering.

Exhibition open to the public (free entry) until November 14.

description:
Smack Bang POP UP Weekend - WGTN, ALL THE JUICY DETAILS
Date: Saturday 30th August and Sunday 31st August
Time: 10AM to ~3PM
Location (indoor): Lyall Bay Junction: 53/70 Kingsford Smith Street, Lyall Bay, Wellington
Come for: nearly everything we sell, just in person - bakery, deli, toys, grooming, treats, accessories, apparel and more. Plenty of pats and features on socials.
Extra Info: Everyone loves freebies. Each day we've got some snacks and x10 seriously cute goodie bags* to give away to the first 10 customers. Think treats, something handy, something soothing etc
Big shout out to our suppliers! Keep an eye on socials for sneak peaks.
Not in Wellington? Don't worry, we've got something for everyone. All purchases made that weekend at the pop up or online will go in the draw to win their order back
this means you get your money or a credit with us back, you choose.
And all purchases $50 and over will get one of our dog keychains** for FREE.
Here's some more exciting information!
DAY ONE: Saturday
Oh Vienna founder Kat will be in Wellington to meet and greet you. She will be available from 10am to 12pm and able to give you the low down on why her engineer designed collars are the best on the market, advice on sizing and help to resize your collar on the spot.
BOTH DAYS: Saturday and Sunday
Abi and Em from the newly branded Your Canine Compass will be available 10am to 12pm to do muzzle fittings as well as give you information on their new training programmes. From puppy, teen, adolescent to adult - they've got you covered.
Specially sent down from Mr Soft Top, is an amazing box of goodies. This will be on top of our current range. Think the best NZ made apparel and blankets. Thanks Rachael and hopefully you can make it next time!
WE'D LOVE TO SEE YOU THERE! RAIN OR SHINE, BUT LET'S HOPE SOME SHINE

description:
Living is Like, Directed by Andrea Ferpo
Once upon a time, there was someone who felt growing up was like constantly being at university, another for whom falling in love was like playing roulette in a casino, and another whose jealousy was like eating spicy food every day.
Living Is Like… harnesses the power of metaphor to unleash the hidden emotions behind our everyday actions, the way we think about ourselves, and how we view each other.

Wellington - Women Paving the Way Discussion Panel, Join us for an evening of inspiration, conversation, and connection at a discussion panel featuring incredible women driving our industry forward — breaking new ground, opening doors for others, and leading with legacy, mentorship, and vision.
Meet the Panel
Erica Cumming – General Manager Strategy & Engagement, Waihanga Ara Rau
Sarah Shiella Skillen – Manager, The Sustainability Society, and recent recipient of a Special Merit for Student Excellence at the NAWIC Excellence Awards
BCITO Apprentice – to be announced
Event Timing
5:30pm – Networking and light refreshments
6:00pm – Discussion Panel
Tickets
Tickets are free, but we invite you to give a koha at checkout in support of the National Council of Women New Zealand — the country’s leading gender equality organisation.
Event partners
A special thanks to our partners BCITO who are empowering women in trades through the new Actions Speak Louder initiative. From practical solutions such as improved hygienic facilities and access to period products, to essential workwear and measures that support injury prevention, these initiatives are creating real change on the frontline- ensuring everyone feels they belongs on site.

description:
Photography - Beginners, Description
If you want to get the best results from your camera, you need to learn the fundamental skills and theory of good photography.

Bring your fully manual-capable (D)SLR or mirrorless camera and owner's manual (if you have one) to the first session.

By the end of the course, you'll be able to:
- Operate your camera in manual mode with more confidence
- Use your camera controls such as shutter speed and aperture with confidence
 Determine a correct exposure
- Present and discuss images in a group environment
- Demonstrate technical concepts through their practical application

A condition of enrolment is that you must provide photo ID when you attend.

NOTE: Compact cameras are not suitable for this course. Includes a Saturday field trip at a date and time to be advised - check individual course details.

Note: Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".


5 sessions, 4 x Thu 7:30 PM – 9:30 PM plus Saturday morning field trip
Wellington High School
Presented by John Williams
$159. incl. GST

description:
Beads & Beers - A Boozy Beading Workshop #3, Join us at our Beads & Beers workshop, courtesy of our local taproom, Abandoned Brewery!

Have a girls night, bring along your dates, mates, and those you relate to for this local collaboration!

Come along and make your own bracelet or keychain, and get your first drink (alcoholic or otherwise) on the house. Additional items can be made on the night for $10 each - eftpos payments available.

We’ll bring a huge selection of beads with us, and Abandoned have a huge selection of craft beers, wines, and other delicious drinks to choose between! Snacks available for purchase too.

Bookings and payments required in advance for people aged 18+. Valid ID required upon entry.

Workshop is held at Abandoned Taproom Petone - 38 Fitzherbert Street.

description:
Smack Bang POP UP Weekend - WGTN, ALL THE JUICY DETAILS
Date: Saturday 30th August and Sunday 31st August
Time: 10AM to ~3PM
Location (indoor): Lyall Bay Junction: 53/70 Kingsford Smith Street, Lyall Bay, Wellington
Come for: nearly everything we sell, just in person - bakery, deli, toys, grooming, treats, accessories, apparel and more. Plenty of pats and features on socials.
Extra Info: Everyone loves freebies. Each day we've got some snacks and x10 seriously cute goodie bags* to give away to the first 10 customers. Think treats, something handy, something soothing etc
Big shout out to our suppliers! Keep an eye on socials for sneak peaks.
Not in Wellington? Don't worry, we've got something for everyone. All purchases made that weekend at the pop up or online will go in the draw to win their order back
this means you get your money or a credit with us back, you choose.
And all purchases $50 and over will get one of our dog keychains** for FREE.
Here's some more exciting information!
DAY ONE: Saturday
Oh Vienna founder Kat will be in Wellington to meet and greet you. She will be available from 10am to 12pm and able to give you the low down on why her engineer designed collars are the best on the market, advice on sizing and help to resize your collar on the spot.
BOTH DAYS: Saturday and Sunday
Abi and Em from the newly branded Your Canine Compass will be available 10am to 12pm to do muzzle fittings as well as give you information on their new training programmes. From puppy, teen, adolescent to adult - they've got you covered.
Specially sent down from Mr Soft Top, is an amazing box of goodies. This will be on top of our current range. Think the best NZ made apparel and blankets. Thanks Rachael and hopefully you can make it next time!
WE'D LOVE TO SEE YOU THERE! RAIN OR SHINE, BUT LET'S HOPE SOME SHINE

description:
The Extravaganza Fair - Wellington / Petone, The Extravaganza Fair - Wellington / Petone
🎪✨ ROLL UP, ROLL UP – THE EXTRAVAGANZA FAIR IS BACK! ✨🎪

🎉 Celebrating 11 epic years of magical mayhem on the road! 🎉

New Zealand’s biggest and most fabulous travelling fair is rolling back into town – and you’re invited!

We’re bringing grassroots charm, vintage flair, and old-school fun to town – a joyride for all ages! Whether you’re 5 or 95, there’s something here to make your heart happy.

💫 FREE ENTRY for kids! Gold coin for adults – that’s it!
Get ready for a weekend packed full of FREE entertainment the whole whānau will love.

Expect a kaleidoscope of colour, creativity, and community vibes with:

🎨 Unique market stalls, arts,crafts & more!
🌮 Yummy street food galore
🎡 Kids rides & games all day
🎭 The fabulous Ashton Family Circus
🐉 Burns the Dragon breathing fun
🧜‍♀️ Enchanting Mermaid Storytime
🎪 Sparkling LuckyStar Zone (as seen at Splore!)
🎶 Live music all day
🔮 Tarot, past-life readings & mystical moments

⚡ Tiny homes, solar setups & sustainable inspiration
🕶️ Retro lounges & shady chill zones = your new favourite hangout spot 🛋️

See you there this summer 2025 - 2026!! 💥 🌼

#extravaganzafair #theextravaganzafair #ontour #nzsummer #nz

description:
The Annual Celebration of Monty Python Day!, The Annual Celebration of Monty Python Day!
And now for something completely different…
Prepare yourself for a day of absurd antics, ridiculous competitions, and nonsensical fun as The Bond Store descends into Monty Python–inspired mayhem.

💰 Entry is FREE!
But to join the day’s silliness, games, and glorious nonsense, we will be asking for a donation to Kāpiti Golf for Good – a Lions & Rotary initiative.

👑 Gather your knights, twits, and lumberjacks for:

🕺 The Ministry of Silly Walks Competition

🩸 The Black Knight’s Limb Toss (just a flesh wound)

🎩 The Upper-Class Twit of the Year Race

🐴 The Two-Person Coconut Horse Race

🌲 The Lumberjack Song Karaoke (he’s okay!)

🧠 The Monty Python Quiz (bring your brain, or a dead parrot)

🏆 Prizes to be won, dignity to be lost.

But that’s not all! Beware of French guards at the gate, pop into the Argument Tent (“This isn’t an argument!”), and expect confusion, silliness, and possibly a Spanish Inquisition (though nobody expects that).

Plus: Market stalls and Monty Python–themed drinks at the bar.

Plus Steve Poulton live music from 4.30pm.

So grab your coconuts and gallop to The Bond Store for a day you won’t forget (no matter how hard you try).

Kindly stuff your pockets with good old-fashioned cash (none of that funny monopoly money) to hurl generously at the ‘Golf is Good’ charity in exchange for your entry into the day’s utterly ridiculous games

WE ARE LOOKING FOR TEAMS AND INDIVIDUALS TO ENTER THE EVENTS - IF YOU ARE KEEN - YOU NEED TO BE QUICK:

a BIG THANK YOU!! to Coastlands for sponsoring great prizes for the day!
label: Markets & Fairs

The Merry-Go-Round Vintage Wares x Herb's Mobile Record Store @ The Wharehaus, We've missed The Merry-go-round's Alicetown bricks-and-mortar shop and it's been a while since we've seen physical music being sold in the Eastern suburbs so we're getting together to put on a collaborative pop-up on the 20th of this month.
These two are masters at curating the weird, obscure and wonderful - vintage bits, furniture, vinyl, cassettes, CD's, tees and retro gaming consoles.
Get along it'll be a blast.

description:
The Waikanae Beach Indoor "Spring" Market, "Spring has Sprung" so why not celebrate its arrival by coming along and enjoying a Sunday outing in Kapiti with your family by visiting the Market where you will discover hand made treasures and local creativity by highly talented stallholders where every piece tells a story.

You will find a huge variety of quality items and gifts along with Plants. Natural Honey, Sewing Craft, Woodwork, Art, jewellery, up-cycled and re-purposed items and lots lots more.

Bring the Kids along so they can meet local author Michael Peryer and view his latest Children's Adventure Books. Jane will be also be there with her hand made Crochet Toys along with Helen and her hand made Children's Dress Ups and Dolls Clothes etc

Meet up with Family and Friends and enjoy a day out on the Kapiti Coast and visit this great friendly Community Market then spend the rest of the day at other events and attractions including a visit to our great cafes.

Don't miss it... support local!

description:
Padi Advanced Open Water Course, Exploration, excitement and experiences are what the PADI Advanced Open Water (AOW) Diver course is all about.

The AOW course is designed for both new and more experienced Open Water Divers and is best attended as soon after your Open Water Diver course as possible. That way you will increase your confidence and build scuba skills to become safer and more comfortable in the water; all under the supervision of a PADI Instructor.

The AOW course consists of five dives that includes a: Deep and an Underwater Navigation dive. Popular local options for the remaining three dives are: Peak Performance Buoyancy, Naturalist, Wreck, Fish Identification, Imaging, Night, *Enriched Air or *Dive Against Debris (* conditions apply).

You may choose to add the 'Enriched Air' and/or the 'Dive Against Debris' specialty qualifications to your weekend experience. Simply ask to: include these dives as part of your five dives, complete the on-line study and a short practical, pay a small fee – and go diving. These Specialties count towards the prestigious PADI Master Scuba Diver rating.

Pay your deposit and you can begin the AOW theory. Make sure your dive medical is current, then join us for a weekend's fun diving. After everything is completed, you will qualify as a PADI AOW Diver. This is the minimum requirement for our dive adventures and a prerequisite for the PADI Rescue Diver course.
If you have any questions, please call so we can help you.

description:
Upper Hutt Gypsy Fair, Upper Hutt Gypsy Fair
The Gypsy Fair is a nationwide travelling event, bringing family fun, live music and an unbeatable vibe to each town we visit.🌞💜

Having been on the road for over 45 years, it’s safe to say our roots run deep. Our people are incredible, and house trucks/buses are pretty cool too! So don’t forget to check out our unique way of living while you’re here 🫶🌿🌻💜

Whether you’re just having a browse, letting the kids loose on our rides, parking up with some food or coffee, or checking out some funky handmade crafts, we would love to see you! Come and hang out for the day, we’re sure to bring smiles to your faces, and create lifelong memories💜

🌞Free entry for everyone🌞 We pride ourselves on being an affordable event for every family. With free entertainment all day, plenty of chill out zones, and loads of life size games laying around, we truely love to see the community getting amongst it all! Can’t wait to see you there🌞👣🐝🌿🌊

Follow us on Facebook – ‘Gypsy Fair’ for updates on our travels and creations! We’re always open to anyone who wants to come and live the dream, so please email us if this sounds like a bit of you. –
label: Markets & Fairs

description:
Titahi Bay Christmas Fair, Titahi Bay Christmas Fair
Welcome to the annual Titahi Bay Christmas Fair, join us on the 21st December at Kura Park, Titahi Bay from 10am to 3pm for a fun family day out just on Christmas.

Our gold coin gate fundraiser this year is Wellington Free Ambulance, look out for the buckets at the gates, please dig a little deep every dollar helps.

We have a great selection of children's entertainment rides and over 160 stallholders showcasing their quality artisan crafted goods.

Fair day is a good time top stock up on those sauces and condiments, crackers from our local artisan food stalls for the BBQ season or as gifts this Christmas.

Join us for brunch/lunch with over 30 foodies covering every corner of the globe to tempt those taste buds.

Friendly reminder to bring some cash as some stalls and foodies do not have eftpos and we are some distance to the nearest atm .

See you on the 21st December

description:
Waikanae Artisan Craft Market (28/9/25), Waikanae Artisan Craft Market (28/9/25)
The Artisan Craft Market is a premium handmade event on Kapiti Coast at Waikanae Memorial Hall. This high-quality market is designed to foster a welcoming and friendly atmosphere. Our vision at Artisan Craft Market is to make the market accessible to those who appreciate shopping locally. We aim to provide a platform that supports local artisans, allowing them to showcase their meticulously crafted, high-quality products. By bringing the market directly to the people, we hope to celebrate and promote the unique talents of our community’s skilled artisans.
label: Markets & Fairs

description:
Friends of Karori Cemetery - 2025 Wellington Heritage Festival: Gallows Tour, Crime, Justice, and the Final Walk.
Delve into the complex history of capital punishment in Wellington with this thought-provoking tour through Karori Cemetery. Gallows shines a light on the people behind the process. Discover their roles in shaping justice, the cases that defined their careers, and the human stories behind a system of ultimate consequence.
Each tour is $10 per person (plus non-refundable booking fee). Children under 12 are free.
Our tour has a maximum capacity of about 15 persons. If there are insufficient tickets remaining for your party, please email us at info@friendsofkaroricemetery.co.nz to check if we can accommodate you.
Please note:
If we have to cancel a tour due to inclement weather or sickness, we will notify you on the day 1 hour before the tour starts by email and on our Facebook page. The booking fee is non-refundable.
This tour is approximately 2 hours long.
This tour contains a number of adult themes and some graphic descriptions so is not suitable for everyone.
Please dress appropriately for the conditions.
While we do our best to guide you on a safe walking route, during the winter months the ground can become slippery in places.
Some of our walks require a moderate degree of fitness and are not suited for those with limited mobility.
There is only one toilet which is located by the cemetery office at the main entrance.
If you have purchased tickets for other people can you please pass our tour information on to them as well.
Please meet us at the shelter (shown as the Historic Chapel on the map at the main entrance)
We look forward to welcoming you to Karori Cemetery.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Wairarapa Bookshop Hop 2025, The best booksellers in Wairarapa have come together to give you the ultimate book-lovers day out in celebration of New Zealand Bookshop Day.

This year, you can collect stamps from 13 new and used Wairarapa Bookshops and enjoy a range of other bookish events all day long.

One of the (many) great things about Wairarapa is we have 13 fantastic bookshops all within an easy 30 minute drive of one another, so it's entirely possible for you to hop around all 13 bookshops in a single day.

Celebrate NZ Bookshop Day with a Wairarapa wide Bookshop Hop. It's your chance to win lots of prizes and stock up your bookshelf.

STEP 1:
Pick up an official passport from any of the participating bookshops - available from all participating stores from Friday October 10th.

STEP 2:
Collect a stamp from each store you visit and make a purchase. Each stamp is an entry into the prize draws for $1,000 in bookshop vouchers.

STEP 3:
Leave your stamped entry with the last bookshop you visit.

This event happens rain or shine!

Register for free to stay up to date and for an extra chance to win a prize: bookshopday.nz/
label: Markets & Fairs

description:
Pukeahu Park Tour, Whether you visit Pukeahu every Anzac Day or pass through on your daily commute, have you ever paused to look closer?
Join us for a walk through the park led by an expert guide, and gain a deeper understanding of Pukeahu, the memorials, and the people they honour.

This special guided tour covers a broad range of narratives, whether you’re interested in design and architecture, place-based histories or want to reflect on New Zealand’s military experiences. This tour will leave you with a lasting understanding of why Pukeahu is such a significant place for all New Zealanders.

The tour begins at the fountain below the Tomb of the Unknown Warrior.
This is an accessible tour. Bring clothing for the weather and any burning questions.
label: Hobbies & Interests

description:
I-Sarn Thai KanTok, Join Daeng from Tuk Tuk Thai for a deeply personal culinary journey to the heart of E-Sarn, the north-eastern region of Thailand she once called home. This one-night-only event celebrates the traditional Kan-Tok style of dining – a communal meal served on handwoven bamboo trays and shared amongst family and friends. This event is made to be shared, the ticket price is for a shared menu for two. 

Growing up in the small town of Tha Bo near the Mekong Delta, Daeng’s childhood was filled with stories of rice farming, village generosity, and dishes cooked from what the garden offered. In E-Sarn, meals were acts of love, shared daily around the Kan-Tok with laughter, music, and warmth.

Now, Daeng invites you to gather at her table and experience the flavours of her upbringing. You’ll be served nine traditional dishes on a beautifully crafted bamboo tray, designed for sharing, just as they are in her village.

On the Kan-Tok:
Hor Mok Salmon – Steamed salmon in banana leaves, marinated with herbs, spices, and coconut milk
Mok Nor Mai with Pork Belly – Pork belly steamed with bamboo shoots
Larb Gai – A celebratory chicken mince salad with fresh herbs and toasted rice
E-Sarn Sausages – House-made, spiced and fermented in true north-eastern style
Nam Prik Tomato – Roasted tomato dipping sauce with chillies, garlic, and shallots
Som Tum – Green papaya salad with a sweet, sour, spicy kick
Sticky Rice – Soaked overnight and steamed in traditional bamboo baskets
Fresh and Steamed Seasonal Vegetables – To enjoy with sauces and mains

Dessert:
Kanom Chan – Thai layered jelly cake
Kanom Mun – Tapioca and coconut pudding

Pull up a seat at Daeng’s table and discover the stories, flavours, and traditions that shaped her childhood.
Single tickets or odd numbers unable to be catered to.
label: Food & Drink

description:
Whānau Day: Kua hoki mai te koekoeā – The koekoeā has returned, Whānau Day: Kua hoki mai te koekoeā – The koekoeā has returned
Ka ako mō te Kōanga mā ngā mahi utukore pai mō te whānau, arā, ngā awheawhe me ngā whakaari.

Learn about kōanga with free family-friendly activities, workshops, and performances.


Kua hoki mai te koekoeā! The koekoeā has returned!


Join us for a day of free activities for tamariki, celebrating the return of kōanga. Watch kapa haka performances, make your own crafts, get your face painted and learn about the manu and plants that signal spring has arrived.

A full schedule, including information for Deaf whānau, to be released soon.


✨ Bookable NZSL session, 10.30am–11.30am

A free, bookable session for Deaf tamariki and their whānau led by a Deaf facilitator, with NZSL Interpreters. 18 places available.

More information will be shared soon. To book your places, please email


Kua hoki mai te koekoeā refers to the koekoeā, or the long-tailed cuckoo returning being a sign that spring is coming, as it is a migratory manu.


🎟️ Entry to Te Papa is free for all New Zealanders and people living in Aotearoa New Zealand.

📅 Don’t miss out on our other events! Stay in the loop at tepapa.nz/newsletter

description:
Upper Hutt Gypsy Fair, Upper Hutt Gypsy Fair
The Gypsy Fair is a nationwide travelling event, bringing family fun, live music and an unbeatable vibe to each town we visit.🌞💜

Having been on the road for over 45 years, it’s safe to say our roots run deep. Our people are incredible, and house trucks/buses are pretty cool too! So don’t forget to check out our unique way of living while you’re here 🫶🌿🌻💜

Whether you’re just having a browse, letting the kids loose on our rides, parking up with some food or coffee, or checking out some funky handmade crafts, we would love to see you! Come and hang out for the day, we’re sure to bring smiles to your faces, and create lifelong memories💜

🌞Free entry for everyone🌞 We pride ourselves on being an affordable event for every family. With free entertainment all day, plenty of chill out zones, and loads of life size games laying around, we truely love to see the community getting amongst it all! Can’t wait to see you there🌞👣🐝🌿🌊

Follow us on Facebook – ‘Gypsy Fair’ for updates on our travels and creations! We’re always open to anyone who wants to come and live the dream, so please email us if this sounds like a bit of you. –

description:
Albi & the Wolves, Gate opens 7pm Music Starts 7.30pm Wednesday 1st October 2025
Auckland based Albi and the Wolves set fire to stages and fill hearts with hope with their energetic and relatable alternative indie folk songs. Proud albino frontman Albi (Chris Dent), Pascal Roggen and Michael Young have crafted a stage show brimming with energy yet with pauses for reflection. The trio has a huge sound created simply by acoustic guitar, electric violin, double bass and three voices. Since 2014, Albi & the Wolves have gone from strength to strength touring Australia, New Zealand and Rarotonga. In 2018, they took home the Best Folk Artist Award at the NZVMAs.
What makes the band special is their sense of community. Whether it’s connection through dance, singing or laughter, their performances inspire audiences to keep coming back for more. Just love them!
Come along and enjoy their great gig in our special space, up close and personal.
Not for profit, supporting our dedicated musicians. Suggested donation $40
Teas, Coffee and Snacks provided. You're welcome to bring anything you'd like to eat or drink.
Parking available in the Coupon zones of Upland Rd & Glasgow St free after 6pm weekdays, and free all through the weekends. The Wilson Carpark at the top of the Cable Car charges 24/7.

description:
Contract Law Fundamentals for Non Lawyers Masterclass Wellington, Contract Law Fundamentals for Non Lawyers Masterclass Wellington
Register Today by contacting Crown Leadership International Group: Website: www.crownleadership.com.au Phone: +64 9 889 7217

About this Event

Contract Law Fundamentals for Non Lawyers Masterclass is an intensely practical guide through the essentials of contract law, exploring such details as when a contract will be required, when you have a contract (and don’t necessarily know it), what types of contract exist and the effect of legislation on your contractual arrangements.
This masterclass also scrutinises what happens when things go wrong, including how you can get out of a contract, options for assessing damages and remedies for breach and looking at the contractual implications of working in an e-commerce environment. You will grasp the crucial ingredients required for a good contract, and gain tips to better understand and manage your contracts.

description:
Kevin Bloody Wilson Aussie Icon Tour, The much-loved and outrageously funny comedian KEVIN BLOODY WILSON is coming back to NZ in August & September with his new “Aussie Icon Tour”, performing again his funniest songs, hilarious stories and shooting down political correctness for his Kiwi fans supported by Jenny Talia from Australia. He’s fair-dinkum funny helping to prevent global boring!
With 350 million TikTok views, 4 million album sales and 6 million tickets sold around the world, Kevin Bloody Wilson shows no signs of slowing down because he says “there is just too much political correctness to incorrect!”
“I love being on stage when every bugger in the audience knows every word to my songs. I now call them my DILLIGAF CHOIR and I don’t think there is a bigger choir in the world than the Kevin Bloody Wilson DILLIGAF CHOIR!” says Kevin.
Since releasing his first hugely popular album “Your Average Australian Yobbo” in 1984 and hit songs like “Hey Santa Claus”, Kevin Bloody Wilson has become a global comedy institution with an extensive multi-generational fan base stretching from the Australian Outback to Buckingham Palace, and that most definitely includes New Zealand. Even Billy Connolly calls him ‘the world’s funniest Australian’. Kev’s irreverent R18 humour may not be to everyone’s taste, but it certainly has been enjoyed by a heck of a lot of Kiwi’s who have laughed and sung along with him on his many tours here since the 1990’s; sharing the ditties that first sparked imaginations with their children and now their grandchildren. His loyal fans should not miss this further opportunity to enjoy another big dose of Kev and for those not yet acquainted you’re invited to enjoy a knee-slapping, hilarious night out.
R18 restriction applies.
Tickets from $66.50 plus booking fees
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
Advanced Yoga Class - Level 6, These classes are for anyone who has done yoga before and is ready for more advanced yoga postures, done with deeper inner focus and concentration. The Level 6 asanas and practices are advanced, and thus require a more concentrated and slow practice, with this the influence deepens. Each asana has a regulatory effect on the organs and glandular systems, the effects unfold during the asana and also during the short relaxation between each asana.

This level includes the practice of the Bhastrika - Pranayama.

Thursdays: 6 - 7.30pm

Drop in: $22 or 10 class card or holders of the Monthly passes

description:
Samoan - Introductory 2 / Ongoing, Samoan - Introductory 2
For those who have done Introductory 1 (16 hours) or have equivalent knowledge e.g. who may have picked up some basic survival language through travel.
By the end of the course, you will: 
• Build on the language and grammar skills learned in the Introductory 1 course
• Have sufficient grammar and vocabulary to conduct a basic conversation in Samoan on everyday topics
• Be able to describe and use (at a basic level) correct sentence structure in Samoan
• Be able to describe traditional Samoan protocols and use these in practice 
NOTE: This course is subsidised with funding from the Tertiary Education Commission (TEC) and you must provide photo ID when you attend your first session.
 Note:  Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

description:
Auckland Kristallnacht Commemorative Concert 2025, The Holocaust Centre of New Zealand must confirm all tickets generated by the Humanitix ticketing system. Once you register, you'll receive an acknowledgement from Humanitix, followed by a second email directly from the Holocaust Centre of New Zealand.
2025 Annual Kristallnacht Commemorative Concert
Escape & Exile – East & West
Join the Holocaust Centre of New Zealand for a poignant evening of remembrance and reflection. The Te Kōkī Trio, featuring Inbal Megiddo (cello), Martin Riseley (violin), and Jian Liu (piano), will be joined by Professor Kim Cunio, Head of Te Kōkī / New Zealand School of Music, in a powerful performance commemorating Kristallnacht.
 This concert commemorates Kristallnacht, or “The Night of Broken Glass,” the horrific pogroms of 9–10 November 1938, across Germany, Austria, and the Sudetenland. This state-sponsored violence saw the murder of an estimated 91 Jews, the arrest of 30,000, and the destruction of hundreds of synagogues and Jewish businesses. Kristallnacht is widely regarded as a pivotal moment, marking the escalation of Nazi persecution and often described as the beginning of the Holocaust.
 The Nazis sought to silence the music and art of all those they deemed "untermenschen," including six million Jews and other victimised groups. This concert stands as a powerful act of defiance and remembrance, allowing us to hear the voices of those who were murdered, forced into hiding, or exiled. It celebrates their artistic brilliance and ensures their memory lives on.
 This year's theme is "Escape and Exile: East and West." In the tradition of paying musical tribute to all victims, we will honour the music of Jewish composers from across the globe—from the Netherlands and Nazi-occupied Germany in the West, all the way to Iraq and Shanghai in the East.
 The programme will feature pieces that honour:
Erna Weiss Falk, a talented Jewish opera singer from Cologne, whose promising career was cut short by anti-Jewish laws. She and her family ultimately escaped to the Netherlands.
Brigitte Schiffer, a young composer who completed her doctorate in Berlin before fleeing the Nazis to Egypt, where she became the director of the Higher Music Education Institute for women.
The Al Kuwaiti brothers, Jewish pioneers of modern Iraqi music, survived the Farhud, a devastating pogrom inspired by Nazi ideology that targeted Baghdad's Jewish population on June 1-2, 1941, coinciding with the Jewish holiday of Shavuot. Despite their legacy resonating across the Middle East through radio, their contributions were erased from Iraqi history.
Ferdinand Adler, a Hungarian Jewish violinist who miraculously escaped from the Dachau concentration camp, to Shanghai.
 Join us for this important event as we mourn the lives lost and celebrate the resilience of the human spirit. We look forward to welcoming you.
 Details:
Wellington: Sunday, 9 November 2025
Auckland: Monday, 10 November 2025
Doors Open: 6:00 PM
Concert Begins: 6:45 PM
Location: To Be Announced
 Please RSVP by Monday, 3 November 2025, to let us know if you can join us.
label: Music & Concerts

description:
British and Irish Film Festival - Broken English, - OFFICIAL SELECTION: Venice International Film Festival 2025 -
- OFFICIAL SELECTION: BFI London Film Festival 2025 -

Broken English is a bold and imaginative documentary portrait of the inimitable singer, songwriter and icon Marianne Faithfull.

A survivor, provocateur and true original, Marianne spent more than six decades defying expectations, releasing over thirty-five albums while constantly reinventing herself.

Made with her full involvement, Broken English is an intimate and unflinching exploration of a fractured yet unbreakable life shaped by fame, creativity and relentless public scrutiny.

The film unfolds within the “Ministry of Not Forgetting”, an imagined, cinematic institution where memory and mythology collide. The Ministry is presided over by Tilda Swinton as The Overseer, and George MacKay (also starring in & Sons at this year’s Festival) serves as The Record Keeper, poring over Faithfull’s life and career.

Broken English is a genre-defying act of resilience and rebellion — Marianne Faithfull’s final fearless declaration, her defiant swan song.
Director
Jane Pollard, Iain Forsyth
Cast
Marianne Faithfull, Tilda Swinton, George MacKay, Zawe Ashton
label: Film & Media

description:
Body Ocean — Live @ Meow, Body Ocean, a dynamic force in the realm of electronic music, specialises in crafting immersive and kinetic house music. Their sonic journey explores the interplay between organic and artificial elements, navigating contrasts between personality and dissolution, as well as the push and pull of extraversion and introspection.

With an impressive catalogue of releases on influential labels such as Size, Black Book Records, Mad Decent, Dirtybird, Box of Cats, and STMPD RCRDS, Body Ocean has firmly established themselves as a notable presence in the electronic music scene. They've also left a lasting mark with remixes for acclaimed artists including Steve Angello, Valentino Khan, Alison Wonderland, Ane Brun, and Mija.

Their commitment to pushing sonic boundaries and exploring diverse musical dimensions sets them apart — fuelling a growing reputation as innovators within the industry.

As they gear up for 2024, Body Ocean is poised to captivate dancefloors with a compelling fusion of sound and a vision that looks firmly to the future of electronic music.

Catch Body Ocean live at Meow on Friday 22nd August — support to be announced.
label: Music & Concerts

description:
NZIFF: The President’s Cake, A young girl scrambles to prepare a high-stakes birthday cake for a dictator amidst the dangers and deprivations of the Gulf War in this irresistibly scrappy Caméra d'Or-winner from Iraq.

Nine-year-old Lamia (Banin Ahmad Nayef in a spectacular debut) lives with her grandmother and beloved rooster in the impoverished but tranquil Iraqi Marshes. Despite barely being able to feed themselves due to crippling food shortages caused by international sanctions, the family is randomly selected to prepare a cake as part of the forced national spectacle observing Saddam Hussein’s birthday.

From bucolic wetlands to bustling city streets, Lamia embarks on an ingredient-hunting odyssey that mixes equal parts sweet absurdity and bitter reality. Bartering with hawkers, dodging authorities, and begging the kindness of strangers, the young girl encounters the full gamut of humanity, from good to grotesque, as she approaches her ludicrous mission with innocent determination.

Director Hasan Hadi deftly evokes humour and open heartedness against a bleak background of oppression and war. Cinematographer Tudor Vladimir Panduru summons rich texture from the gorgeous locations, beautifully backed by a flowing soundtrack of traditional strings. — Adrian Hatwell
label: Film & Media

description:
Bob McNeill & Emily Roughton in concert, Bob McNeill & Emily Roughton in concert
DATE: Saturday Sept 27
TIME: 7pm
LOCATION: The Offering – 65 Main St, Greytown
AGES:
COST: $25 pp at the door or booking link below

Bob McNeill & Emily Roughton are two of New Zealand’s best-known folk musicians. They bring their deep musical connection to festivals across New Zealand, playing their favourite songs and tunes collected over years of playing together at festivals, stages and late into the night at kitchen tables. Based in Wellington, Bob is one of NZ’s best-known folk songwriters and a favourite with Greytown audiences. His songs have been covered by artists in NZ, Australia, the UK and the USA. New Zealand Musician magazine compared his songwriting to Bruce Springsteen and Mark Knopfler; the Dominion Post likened him to Jackson Brown, James Taylor, Luka Bloom and Dougie Ma¬cLean. A guitarist, he is known for his distinctive open-tuned acoustic fingerstyle and electric guitar playing. He has toured widely in NZ, Australia, Canada, Ireland, the UK and the USA. His latest album, released in June 2024, is Lost Stars, an extended release on CD and download featuring new recordings and rarities, with Emily on violin and piano.

From Whangarei, Emily is a virtuoso violinist inspired by the Scottish tradition and the modern trad movement. Classically trained, she is infinitely adaptable with her gorgeous stylings and fiery tune playing, making her the perfect foil for Bob’s lyrical songs.

Don’t miss a chance to see these two consummate musicians share their foot-stomping collection of banging tunes, favourite songs and stolen moments from the last 20 years.

Book your tickets here:
https://greytownarttown.com/bob-mcneill-and-emily-roughton-in-concert/
label: Music & Concerts

description:
Burgin, Kerr & Norman, The Undercurrent presents Burgin, Kerr & Norman

A swampy melting pot of country, folk, americana and blues, they combine a mutual love of story-telling and rhythmic grooves with narratives about the human experience. Original material from each member, with a wide range of instrumentation including piano, acoustic and Weissenborn guitars, accordion, bodhran, and percussion.

Irishman Andrew Kerr (ex. Jacky Tar) and Alan Norman (The Warratahs, The Rag Poets) formed a trio with Paddy Burgin (The Wooden Box Band, The Zimmermans). Paddy, a world-renowned luthier who featured on Andrew and Alan’s critically acclaimed 2023 release ‘For the Record’ described as …

“…..one of the year’s best albums in Americana/folk ….a thoughtful, passionate, and
musically rich collection that holds up under repeated listens….”

description:
Genealogy - Basics of Ancestry.com DNA Tests, Have you done a DNA test with Ancestry.com? Don't know what to do next? This course will cover the basics of what your DNA results mean. We'll look at the tools available on Ancestry.com and other DNA websites to help you use DNA for your family's history.

Got your test results back and still wondering what a centiMorgan or a shared match is? Find out what the size of your match means and the tools available to help you work out possible family relationships.

We'll start by looking at Clustering and how the Grouping tool on Ancestry.com can help with this. We'll also look at the ThruLines and Common Ancestors tools to see how they can provide suggestions for knocking down brick walls in your research.

Also covered during this course are other websites you can upload your results to, how to manage other family member's DNA test results and other tools available when you get a bit more advanced - and just in case you need help in the future, we'll look at some of the places you could get this from.

Please note: This course will only cover DNA tests taken through Ancestry.com

Bring a USB stick and your Ancestry.com login details.

By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:
- Understand the information provided by Ancestry.com about your DNA matches
- Use the Grouping, ThruLines and Common Ancestors tools on Ancestry.com
- Use the Shared CentiMorgan tool on DNAPainter.com
- Understand where to find other tools
- Understand the options for using other DNA websites
- Understand where to get further help

Prerequisites
For those who have already done a DNA test through Ancestry.com
You will need good computing and internet skills.

Note: Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

Presented by Sarah Hewitt.

After an unforgettable run of shows across Aotearoa in January, acclaimed troubadour,
C.W. Stoneking makes his much-anticipated return this spring.

Presale 10am (NZST), Friday 15th August
General on sale 10am (NZST), Monday 18th August
Tickets from Banished Music
Register for presale at banishedmusic.com/subscribe

With his unmistakable swagger, Stoneking moves effortlessly between the red dust of Alice Springs and the deep grooves of the American South. Drawing on a heady blend of vintage blues, New Orleans jazz, gospel, calypso, country and western kitsch, he conjures a sound that is both timeless and thrillingly original.
Audiences can expect zombie shuffles, gospel stompers, and tropical torch songs – all delivered with wit, charm, and musical brilliance. Rich in character, darkly funny, and steeped in storytelling, Stoneking’s music may evoke a bygone era, but his performances crackle with electricity.

description:
Cliff Richard - Can't Stop Me Now, Cliff Richard - Can't Stop Me Now
British music icon Sir Cliff Richard announced his highly anticipated live tour for New Zealand 2025. These shows offer a rare chance to witness one of Britain’s most celebrated performers in a live setting.

Next year will mark 12 years since New Zealand audiences have seen Cliff Richard live in concert and the 2025 tour will begin in Auckland and make its way to Wellington & Christchurch. Fans will be treated to a setlist packed with timeless classics, including hits such as "Living Doll," "We Don’t Talk Anymore," "Devil Woman," and many more. Known for his energy, charisma, and enduring stage presence, Sir Cliff continues to capture hearts and inspire audiences as he has done across the eight decades.

As one of the greatest hitmakers in British music history, Cliff Richard has sold in excess of 250 million records worldwide, securing his place among the best-selling artists of all time. He remains the only artist to achieve UK Top 5 albums across eight consecutive decades, a remarkable feat recognised by the Official Charts Company. Since his debut in 1958 with “Move It!”, Sir Cliff has delivered a string of chart-topping hits, including 14 number-one singles and seven No. 1 albums, cementing his legacy as a pop legend.

These 2025 performances offer fans a rare opportunity to see one of music’s all-time greats in concert at the age of 85.

description:
Colette Rivers - The Backyard Wonder tour, Colette Rivers - The Backyard Wonder tour
Indie-Folk Artist Colette Rivers and her band will be performing her intimate new album, The Backyard Wonder.

Independent artist Colette Rivers is releasing her second full-length album, The Backyard Wonder, an intimate exploration of healing, change, and the quiet beauty of ordinary moments.

This album holds special meaning for Rivers: after being diagnosed with cancer in July 2023, her planned sophomore release had to take a back seat to recovery. But when the cancer returned in early 2025, she felt compelled to finish and release the album, not just as a legacy project, also as a celebration after hard times, with a focus on how “you can find the wonder in life, even in your backyard.”

A lifelong creative, Rivers records, mixes, and produces in her home studio in Masterton, and plays every instrument heard on The Backyard Wonder. Her debut album, Memory Lake (2020), was shaped by early years spent in the US, and her move to Taupō at age 11; this was followed by a nationwide tour. Now based in the Wairarapa and working as a secondary school drama teacher, Rivers continues to move between solo performance and full band sets, while staying rooted in the acoustic traditions that define her sound.

With her right arm partially paralysed following recent treatment, Rivers has gathered a group of close friends to help bring the songs of The Backyard Wonder to life (especially its intricate fingerpicking parts) for a run of live shows. She’ll be touring the Wellington and Wairarapa regions from August through October, finishing with a set at the Wellington Folk Festival.

For updates, and behind-the-scenes glimpses, visit www.coletteriversmusic.com or follow @colettemusic on Instagram and Facebook.

Opening for Rivers are artists:

Phil Masters
Phil Lively-Masters is an experienced, well travelled singer songwriter who specialises in writing the sort of Sun Kissed West Coast Laurel Canyon Americana that made Neil Young, Stephen Stills and the Byrds famous. With a powerful, honey soaked voice that has won praise and support slots from legendary American country rock pioneers like The Jayhawks and original cosmic cowboy Steve Young, Phil has 20 years worth of road worn original songs to pull on, including tracks from the critically acclaimed CANYON RYDE album 'Free To Be' and some choice country rock covers to weave a spell on any listener.

Saali Marks
A singer, songwriter, guitarist and multi-instrumentalist, Saali Marks hails originally from the
South Island, but has made Wairarapa his home for the last 20 years, where he lives on a farm
with his family and teaches music at Kuranui College.
Saali has played in numerous bands over the years, in a wide range of styles from proto-punk
to psychedelic dub, covers, originals and fully improvised music with no discernible genre, on
stages throughout Aotearoa since 1991. Currently he fronts the Wellington ska band Battleska
Galactica.
Throughout and alongside it all Saali has indulged his love for songwriting and solo
performing, developing a unique style, rooted in folk and blues, and inspired by greats from
across the decades. A skilled guitarist, Saali rarely plays straight ahead chords, and an
education in jazz has informed his ear for harmony, the beauty of dissonance, tension and
resolution, with unconventional song structures, alternate tunings and intriguing melodies.
Although not adverse to penning the odd love song, most of Saali’s lyrics tend to focus on
other aspects of the human condition, from religion and politics to our relationships with the
environment and our own minds.

Tom Cunliffe writes folk songs like short films; vivid, offbeat, and full of heart. Based in Tamaki Makaurau, Auckland, he crafts lyrical worlds, with a guitar tuned sideways and a voice that balances gravity with joy.
Cunliffe has supported a number of internationally renowned artists including M. Ward, Grace Cummings, and Reb Fountain, bringing his mix of warmth, wit, and slow-burning intensity to stages near and far.

Ali Whitton is an Aotearoa-born, Yorkshire-raised and now Wellington based singer-songwriter who is stepping into his own as an artist. Ali is an artist who refuses to let go, blending raw storytelling with a sound shaped by decades of experience and dedication to his craft.
Performing for years under the name Lost Bird, Ali built a reputation for writing heartfelt, melancholic folk-pop, playing everywhere from Wellington bars to stadium stages — including opening for Ed Sheeran in Auckland in 2018.
Now, after years of performing behind an alias, Ali is stepping forward under his own name, embracing his identity as an artist with an invigorated sense of purpose, and tackling his artistry with newfound confidence and clarity.

description:
Calligratherapy - Beginners, Calligratherapy combines science journalist James Nestor's theory on proper breathing with the philosophy of ancient Chinese calligraphy to promote a state of optimal wellbeing. Over five weeks, you will develop and practice the awareness of healthy breathing while learning new techniques of Chinese soft brush calligraphy covering five different scripts.

Description
Many of us live sedentary lifestyles, sitting for up to eight hours or more a day hunched over our keyboard - all the while rarely taking a proper breath! Even if we wanted to take a deep enriching breath into the lower lobes of our lungs, we are limited due to our posture. Often due to the stresses and strains of a busy work and life balance, our unconscious brain can develop a pattern of holding, irregular and shadow breaths.

Does this sound like your experience?

Not being able to breathe properly is the key cause of many chronic respiratory diseases (Nestor, 2020)

Calligratherapy combines science journalist James Nestor's theory on proper breathing with the philosophy of ancient Chinese calligraphy to promote a state of optimal wellbeing.

Calligratherapy has been developed specifically for those who have never practiced calligraphy before and who are interested in deriving the benefits without having to learn the language or all the characters. It integrates the simple and intuitive act of inhaling and exhaling into calligraphy practice with Eastern philosophy behind it.

A range of different breathing exercises are embedded into each 90-minute session focusing on different calligraphy scripts. Over the five weeks, you will develop and practice the awareness of healthy breathing, while learning new techniques of Chinese soft brush calligraphy covering five different scripts.

All materials included in course fee.

By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:

Start a new creative practice in Chinese soft brush calligraphy
Develop your own mindfulness strategy
Better manage everyday stress levels and access a calm, empowered and positive state of mind
Find ways to explore eastern philosophy and develop deeper connections with your spiritual self.

Note: Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".


Duration 5 weeks, Thu 5:30 PM – 7:00 PM

description:
Men’s Circle: Real Conversations, Men’s Circle: Real Conversations
In a world where men are often expected to have everything figured out, this gathering offers a space to be genuine, not perfect.

About this Event

Men’s Circle: Real Conversations
In a society where men are expected to always have it together, this space is for being honest, not perfect.
This is a free offering but there’s the option to stay for an amazing plant-based dinner ($15). There’s no pressure to join, but sitting down to eat together is a simple, powerful way to deepen the sense of connection. Andre & Sri Jiva aren’t running this circle for profit and they are genuinely invested in creating real, meaningful spaces for men to connect.
The Men’s Circle is a gathering where men are able to connect in a safe, supportive space to share experiences, express emotions, and foster personal growth. Free from societal expectations of stoicism or self-sufficiency. Through open sharing and mutual support, participants are empowered to build resilience, self-reflection, and a stronger sense of identity and purpose.
Structure of the Circle
Gathering in a Circle: Participants sit in a circle to symbolize equality and unity.A short meditation or moment of silence may be included to help everyone arrive and connect.
Talking Object: A sharing stick or object is placed in the center. Only the personholding the object may speak, ensuring uninterrupted sharing.
Open Sharing: Anyone may choose to share while holding the object. Sharing is op-tional, and passing is always respected.
Active Listening: While one person shares, others listen attentively without speaking,interrupting, or offering advice. The focus is on witnessing and being present.
No Judgments or Advice: Participants refrain from judging or offering unsolicitedadvice, creating a safe space for authentic expression.
Closing: The circle may conclude with a group reflection, a moment of gratitude, or a simple acknowledgment of the shared experience.
Circle Agreements
Supportive Environment: We are here to uplift and support one another, fosteringtrust and brotherhood.
Focus on the Present: Share whats alive for you now, focusing on your emotions and experiences to deepen emotional awareness.
Use "I" Statements: Speak from your personal perspective using "I" statements topromote authenticity and responsibility. Avoid generalizations like "we" or "us."
No Judgment or fixing: Refrain from judging others sharing or offering unsolicitedadvice, ensuring a safe and non-critical space.
Confidentiality: What is shared in the circle stays in the circle. You may discuss your own experience outside the group, but keep others details private.




Event followed by a plant-based dinner and dessert, all included in your ticket!

What’s on the menu?
Creamy Farfalle Pasta with Plant-Based Bacon
Toasted Bruschetta with “Cheese”, Tomato and Parsley
Fresh Salad with Balsamic Vinegar
Berry Vanilla Muffins with Whipped Cream




Meet Your Hosts: Andre and Sri Jiva
Andre has been immersed in men’s work since the age of 13, when he first experienced a rite of passage in Golden Bay. That formative experience sparked a lifelong connection to circle work, which he later deepened by returning as a mentor. A multi-instrumental musician, poet, and pranayama (breathwork) facilitator, Andre also brings his passion for ecstatic dance, philosophy, and authentic connection into his offerings. He is deeply inspired by the question of what it means to be human—how we can more fully experience our aliveness, our depth, and reconnecting with the beauty of life together.
Since childhood, Sri Jiva has been fascinated by meaning, purpose, and authentic life fulfilment. This, among other things, led him to join a monastery at the age of 19. After years of monastic training, he chose to marry and pursue a career. He felt called to use his monastic experience to help others understand themselves, and to find wisdom, meaning, and purpose in their own lives. Inspired by this calling, he went to university to study counselling. Now, Sri Jiva and his wife live near Wellington, where he works with a small team of counsellors, supporting clients individually and in groups.




Agenda


🕑: 05:30 PM - 05:45 PM
Arrive to Bhakti Lounge

🕑: 05:45 PM - 07:15 PM
Men's Circle: Honest Conversations & Connection
Host: Andre

🕑: 07:15 PM - 08:15 PM
Plant-based dinner and dessert!

description:
Dan Hayles Presents | On The Grid, On The Grid is about the marking, passing and embellishing of time. The Grid is life, time, tone, tonality, rhythm, gravity, momentum, and style. 

The musicians work at times together, other times separately as 3 ensembles (horn quintet, string quartet, piano trio), and other times as combinations conversing and improvising amongst themselves. The music covers a selection of different styles and feels within and outside the jazz sound - and it's ready for your participation as a listener of melodies, dancer of beats, expresser of moods, theorist of lore, interpreter of meaning, and feeler of feels.

On The Grid consists of brand new music arranged and composed especially for the Jazz Composer Orchestra series, originally curated and presented by Michael Costeloe with funding from Creative New Zealand in 2025. This show celebrates the release on CD of the group's first ever performance - buy a copy and help us take On The Grid to more audiences around Aotearoa and the world.

Sylvester Green - Trumpet
Tyaan Singh - Alto Saxophone

description:
Cowboy Dan: Dreams That Feel Like Falling Aotearoa Album Tour - Te Whanganui-a-Tara / Wellington, Cowboy Dan: Dreams That Feel Like Falling Aotearoa Album Tour - Te Whanganui-a-Tara / Wellington
Tāmaki Makaurau jangle rockers Cowboy Dan are releasing their debut full length album; Dreams That Feel Like Falling. The album drops 19 September on streaming & vinyl.

Never overblown or overproduced, Dreams That Feel Like Falling is direct and intimate. 11 tracks of warmth, sincerity and brashness that strike a balance of breeze and overdrive.

To celebrate the release, Cowboy Dan are heading out for a run of shows throughout Te Ika-a-Māui in September and October.

This Te Whanganui-a-Tara will be the second outing in the capital for Cowboy Dan, who are delighted to bring Echo Children along for the ride from Tāmaki to share their special tunes and infectous harmoines, along with Te Whanganui-a-Tara local legends Search For Yeti...STACKED!

Once aptly described as The Bats on the right amount of Red Bull, Cowboy Dan has been treating audiences across the motu to energetic, emotionally charged tunes since 2015. Their live shows have consistently delivered good times to fans and new friends alike.

Off the back of two delightful EPs: We Will Hesitate, When We Eventually Wait (2017, Mixed by Jonathan Pearce); Sentimental Now That We're Leaving (2021, Mixed by Rohan Evans), the debut LP, Dreams That Feel Like Falling, is a continuation and a few steps forward, showcasing the bands expansive sonic pallet, with a mix of distortion, introspection, heart and bite.

Search For Yeti draws from a deep range of influences to create a sound that achieves the difficult feat of being hugely atmospheric and diverse while also being hook laden. This is an act that captures people with their onstage energy — and gets them talking afterwards about the songs that they just heard.

Following in the long tradition of innovative Aotearoa indie bands, Echo Children craft a distinctive sound by melding psychedelic pop harmonies with sharp alt-country songwriting.

Gather your pals and get ready for good times! A thursday, sure, but what a chance to digest some upbeat goodness hailing from the big smoke and with some local goodness to boot.
label: Music & Concerts

description:
HIGHLAND BALL 2025 - TICKETS!!, HIGHLAND BALL 2025 - TICKETS!!
Hi All, Time for a Celebration as our Highland Ball is back on the Calendar for this year!!!
This Ball will be a memorial to Dorothy Shaw who sadly passed away in March and has been our longest serving committee member for around 50 years.
Come along for some real Scottish fun and enjoy the live music, the dancing and our wonderful supper.
Dance practice dates will be available later for those who would like to brush up on their foot work.
Ticket prices: Members $55.00 & Non-Members $65.00
We have tried very hard this year to reduce the ticket prices so everyone can come along and enjoy this wonderful evening.
For any other information please feel free to contact - Robyn
label: Community & Culture

Location: Tawa Pool

description:
Colette Rivers - The Backyard Wonder tour, Colette Rivers - The Backyard Wonder tour
Indie-Folk Artist Colette Rivers and her band will be performing her intimate new album, The Backyard Wonder.

Independent artist Colette Rivers is releasing her second full-length album, The Backyard Wonder, an intimate exploration of healing, change, and the quiet beauty of ordinary moments.

This album holds special meaning for Rivers: after being diagnosed with cancer in July 2023, her planned sophomore release had to take a back seat to recovery. But when the cancer returned in early 2025, she felt compelled to finish and release the album, not just as a legacy project, also as a celebration after hard times, with a focus on how “you can find the wonder in life, even in your backyard.”

A lifelong creative, Rivers records, mixes, and produces in her home studio in Masterton, and plays every instrument heard on The Backyard Wonder. Her debut album, Memory Lake (2020), was shaped by early years spent in the US, and her move to Taupō at age 11; this was followed by a nationwide tour. Now based in the Wairarapa and working as a secondary school drama teacher, Rivers continues to move between solo performance and full band sets, while staying rooted in the acoustic traditions that define her sound.

With her right arm partially paralysed following recent treatment, Rivers has gathered a group of close friends to help bring the songs of The Backyard Wonder to life (especially its intricate fingerpicking parts) for a run of live shows. She’ll be touring the Wellington and Wairarapa regions from August through October, finishing with a set at the Wellington Folk Festival.

For updates, and behind-the-scenes glimpses, visit www.coletteriversmusic.com or follow @colettemusic on Instagram and Facebook.

Opening for Rivers are artists:

Phil Masters
Phil Lively-Masters is an experienced, well travelled singer songwriter who specialises in writing the sort of Sun Kissed West Coast Laurel Canyon Americana that made Neil Young, Stephen Stills and the Byrds famous. With a powerful, honey soaked voice that has won praise and support slots from legendary American country rock pioneers like The Jayhawks and original cosmic cowboy Steve Young, Phil has 20 years worth of road worn original songs to pull on, including tracks from the critically acclaimed CANYON RYDE album 'Free To Be' and some choice country rock covers to weave a spell on any listener.

Saali Marks
A singer, songwriter, guitarist and multi-instrumentalist, Saali Marks hails originally from the
South Island, but has made Wairarapa his home for the last 20 years, where he lives on a farm
with his family and teaches music at Kuranui College.
Saali has played in numerous bands over the years, in a wide range of styles from proto-punk
to psychedelic dub, covers, originals and fully improvised music with no discernible genre, on
stages throughout Aotearoa since 1991. Currently he fronts the Wellington ska band Battleska
Galactica.
Throughout and alongside it all Saali has indulged his love for songwriting and solo
performing, developing a unique style, rooted in folk and blues, and inspired by greats from
across the decades. A skilled guitarist, Saali rarely plays straight ahead chords, and an
education in jazz has informed his ear for harmony, the beauty of dissonance, tension and
resolution, with unconventional song structures, alternate tunings and intriguing melodies.
Although not adverse to penning the odd love song, most of Saali’s lyrics tend to focus on
other aspects of the human condition, from religion and politics to our relationships with the
environment and our own minds.
label: Music & Concerts

description:
Leadlight Glass - 4 Weeks Block, Learn to create gorgeous leadlight designs with our experienced jewellers! This great course runs from Friday 12 September for 4 weeks until Friday 3 October, 5.30pm - 8pm.

Your 4-week block will give you time to learn the basics and then create one or more leadlight projects.

This class is ideal for creating sun-catchers or small decorative projects for beginners, or working on slightly more complex pieces for those with some experience.

Beginners will start by planning their design, then learning to cut the glass, and prepare it before foiling and soldering each piece, creating a simple elegant clear glass starter project.

Beautiful coloured glass, copper foil and leadlight solder are then available to purchase as required for your other projects.

This is a warm and friendly class with excellent support and learning for complete beginners and more advanced students. All tools are supplied, though you are welcome to bring your own tools and glass if you have them.

Your materials for your beginner project are supplied as part of your course fee, extra materials will be available for purchase if you wish to make larger pieces or more than one project.
label: Classes & Workshops
